We brought our own cardboard and left some behind for others who didn't bring their own. Parking is a little tight if you have a big car, but it's San Francisco so that's part of the charm. The park has no restroom, so if you have little ones make sure they go before you go to this park. One great feature is that it is FREE. Very nice for families on a budget and looking to make memories.
author: Bart H.

description:
FEAR NOT, FUN FOLK!  

We visited today specifically to confirm whether or not the "fun has been destroyed" rumors were true and found no evidence that the slides had been sanded.  If the "dreamkillers" had visited, magic elves have since worked their charms because the slides were fine today.

They did seem a slight bit slower, but it rained last night and residual drops from the overhanging branches were causing the cardboard to bind.

Still tops in my book!
author: Violet S.

description:
Probably our favorite thing we did in San Francisco.  We didn't even mind the smell of urine and dog crap.  There were already nicely broken up cardboard boxes for us to slide down on the slides.  Our two-year-old son loved it and soon wanted to go it alone, and without the cardboard.  It's just nice to experience something the way the locals do for a change.   After that we hit Hot Cookie and got a couple cookies and my baby daddy was groped by a harmless-looking spanish man.  He has a shaved head -- what are you going to do?

We got lucky because somebody sort of pointed us in the right direction.  I had no idea what to expect, and I guess I was thinking it would be in a small park.  Not so, it is tucked away between two homes.
author: A V.

description:
If you can have fun VERY QUIETLY it would be a five star, but the mean neighbors who don't seem to understand how a playground is used really wreck the whole experience. And the lady taking pictures of us was definitely on the creepy side and really upset my nine year old. After repeatedly trying to get my four year old not to scream on the descent, I had to drag her away screaming because she wanted to keep sliding.

If you have very very quiet children (or bring duct tape for their mouths?) the slides are great fun.

I'd suggest a walk over to Kite Hill also for an amazing view.
author: Scott M.

description:
BEWARE of the yellow blockades! They apparently go up whenever they don't want people going down the slides! I believe they normally go up when the park is suppose to be closed to prevent people from playing after hours. However, when I went on a semi-wet (rainy) day last week, they were still up during normal hours. We even went and got our own dry cardboard to use!

Such sadness... I was so excited to go play again. This has never happened in the past. I usually go during normal park hours and had never encounter any trouble from angry neighbors. There are always kids playing on the slide so be careful not to run any of them over. Remember, kids are kids and more often than not they don't know how to take turns. Just let them go first. 

Overall, this slide is awesome. It is like a mini-roller-coaster ride. With some cardboard, you will go fast and might even catch a little bit of air.
author: Angela T.

description:
Okay, first off, the slides are awesome. Two long steep concrete contraptions in this random little mini-park? I love San Francisco.

But, unfortunately, this little haven of fun is surrounded by some not so happy people.

I came here today around two or so, with a group of 15 middle schoolers, and four other adults, as part of a summer camp field trip. Our plan was to hang at the slides for 20-30 minutes, then head over to another spot for the rest of the day.

Yes, our kids were loud. They are loud kids, and they were whooping and shrieking and having a freakin' awesome time on those slides.

One woman came, and politely asked us to be a little bit quieter. We apologized, asked the kids to lower their voices (which they did), and continued sliding.

Then, the next door neighbor came out, and started yelling at us AND taking pictures of our kids. "There are too many kids, they're so noisy, I can hear it, you're so disrespectful, you shouldn't be here, blah blah blah."

We apologized, and told her we were leaving.

"NO, I am trying to make a point. I live here, you need to respect the space, this is a peaceful neighborhood..."

The kids even started apologizing, loudly, I admit, but this seemed to piss her off more. She really needed to make a point, but I'm really not sure what point she wanted to make.

Now, the kids I work with are urban youth from neighborhoods like Bayview and the Tenderloin. They are all black and Hispanic, and they go to shitty schools, and many have fucked up home lives. This trip to the slides, like a lot of what we do at my program, was an attempt to get them to experience some of the better parts of childhood, because most of them are growing up too fast. 

While it seems like a lot of people have complained about the unhappy neighbors, some of the kids mentioned that they thought the woman was racist. Maybe. Maybe not. But an old white woman in a million dollar Noe Valley/Castro house yelling at children of color for behaving, like, well, children? Makes you think.

My boss, when she found out about the trip, asked if I had told the woman off. I hadn't, because that's the kind of thing that gets ya fired. My boss told me I should have. I really wish I had.

If you don't like the noise level of your neighborhood, move. I'm sure you can afford it.
author: Erin M.

description: One of the reasons that makes SF so great. Where else can you find a random pair of cement slides? It's true about the cardboard -- luckily there were some clean pieces we found at the end of the slides. There were a couple of other couples there, so it was really chill. Joe thinks the right one gives you a little bit of air time. ;)
author: Mel G.

description:
I discovered the slides online yesterday looking for fun free stuff to do in San Francisco lol We're broke college kids and wanted to have a good time.

My best friend and I got some pizza boxes and my boyfriend got some McDonald's trays. [don't go down without something under you lol too slow and not fun] 

It was so much fun! I went down with the cardboard first and that was ok but as others have said, I definitely recommend grabbing yourself a plastic tray from McDonalds or something. It's soo much better! It seems kinda scary the first time but trust me, totally worth it and pretty safe for the most part just be sure to put your hands up! =)

Another great thing is once it got dark, we got bored and wondered around a bit. We turned a few streets and ended up on Castro St. A fun little end to the day. 

Words of advice: 
-Bring a plastic fast food tray, if you can't get one then cardboard is ok. 
-Wear long pants. 
-Put your arms up. 
-Try the left slide first, it seems funner/faster then the right. 


Definitely recommend going here for some simple free fun if you're in the area. =)
author: Tiara H.

description:
The slides are fun, and the garden above is a gem. But the immediate neighbors to the South are utterly insane. They expect to have quiet 24/7 when they essentially live next to a playground. It's one thing to be mad at people who trespass at night, but harassing preschoolers and their parents at 2 PM is simply delusional.

My son's preschool group visits the slides for 45 minutes every Friday at the end of the school day. The kids play on the slides while the parents and teachers catch up a bit. The noise level is absolutely normal for a group of preschoolers. The school helps to maintain both the garden above the slides and Acme Alley, which is adjacent to this lovely little park.

Last Friday the neighbors asked us to be quiet several times (they were "trying to nap") and then, when the noise level was still not to their liking, proceeded to insult our group repeatedly and basically intimidate us to the point of leaving. They made negative comments about our appearance, called one dad bad names in front of his kids, attempted to make one mom feel bad about breastfeeding an infant in public, and refused to communicate with those of us that attempted to address their concerns in a civil manner.

Several people from our group called the Mission Police Station for advice. They already knew about this situation and were clearly on our side. They advised us to call the police dispatch the next time we are harassed: (415) 553-0123. They also said we can file a restraining order.

I encourage anyone who is confronted by these crazy women to call the police dispatch. This is a neighborhood children's park and should be enjoyed as such.
author: Viola T.

description:
First thing's first, it's NOT on Douglass, it's on Seward. I know it's seemingly obvious based on the name, but after you've hiked up endless hills to get there from Dolores Park, your judgment's a little hazy. 

So once you're on Seward, it's just around the point where the street curves. You're bound to find fellow peeps huffing from their last mini adrenaline rush coming down the slides. 

It's BYOC, but if you forgot your cardboard at home, there's a number of discarded ones for the taking. You may also find a fast food tray. If you opt for the McDonald's version of the slides, prepare yourself for a massively fast bombing down the slide. For those less daring, cardboard does just fine, and you can even toss a little sand on the slides to increase speed. 

Keep your hand up or close or generally away from the walls (you don't want a mangled hand) and don't worry, you likely won't go flying off the bottom of the slide and faceplanting into the floor.

A must for anyone who fancies him or herself an urban adventurer at heart.
author: Monica S.

description: Everytime i can get here with my kid: its closed.  Hella lame.  Even if I go there directly after his camp finishes at like 5pm.  If it needs to close at all, they should close it at like 7 or 8pm; and it should be open every day of the week.  If the neighbors need to close the park that they moved in next to, for noise purposes, they should pay for the staff to do that.  (BTW: I don't enjoy being a hater, but I've been here like 5 times trying to get a ride for my kids, and it was locked EVERY time, even when it was during "open" hours.
author: Fiid W.

description:
Best cement slides I've been on.  For a faster ride, use the plastic trays from McDonalds to go reallllllyyy fast!  Also, I love the people that go there too, just overall nice people who are having a great time.

But.  The crazy troll lady.  She's crazy, yelling at us to keep it quiet, just because we're having a good time.  Lol, the young woman near me dared her to call the police if we were really that much of a bother, but if not, that crazy lady should be quiet and stop being a grouch.  And then she disappeared.  Back to her cave, probably waiting to yell at more people in the future.
author: John S.

description:
Went yesterday and...

I couldn't go down the slides! I would scoot my way to the tip of the decline and go down for like six inches and come to halt...in the middle of the decline...then I'd slide off the cardboard and go down a few more inches on my jeans until they got stuck and started slipping off enough to scare the crap out of me before I come to another halt. We gave up after several more failed attempts and let a kid and his dad have their fun...getting stuck on the slides, too.

Ideas I came up with for next time:
Wear a waxed jumpsuit or
Glue the cardboard on my butt or 
Wear waterproof pants and hose down the slides or
Bring my boyfriend's skateboard or
Bring a broom to sweep off the sand
author: Jennifer L.

description:
WTF, fun slides in the middle of nowhere? Which supervisor authorized this pork barrel spending? They should have built the slides in Union Square where we can all enjoy them daily during our lunch breaks. It's heart breaking how isolated these concrete chutes are.

But alas I found them, hell yeah I did. And I even had a whole beer in me when I did. Oh plus, it was 1am. Hell yes.

So yeah they are scarier than they look. I thought my pants were going to rip off if I fell off my little cardboard box. But I didn't fall off the box, so I'm really not sure if there is serious nudity risk. I'll give it a nudity probability rating of 10%

Anyways if you haven't already, freaking go find this place, it's crazy. Kinda like the twilight zone, or the nexus of the universe, or something. You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll run up the hill and go again.

Tomorrow I'm going to find a contractor to build me a slide in the Yelp office, or maybe a fireman's poll. We need more schoolyard modes of transport in our daily lives.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
This is a San Francisco must for all ages! I can't believe it took me so long to actually check it out. Bring your own cardboard, but you'll most likely find some remnants at either the top or foot of the slide that you can use. 

I love that it's a community-run park and was developed because of the neighborhood coming together. Good SF stuff. 

You'll giggle and scream for joy, reconnecting with your inner child, for real.
author: Lee H.

description:
Made me feel like a kid again! So much fun! 

It also made me feel extremely old, seeing as I haven't had this much fun doing something free in god knows how long. Definitely the place to take kids, nephews, nieces what have you. They'll have the time of their lives just like my friend and I did. 

Technically you're supposed to go with kids and we saw a couple there with their dads. But I guess me and my friend kind of kicked them out because they decided to leave shortly after we got there (sorry kiddies!). There's a sign there that says no adults unless accompanied by children, probably to ward against creepers. But two girls aren't too creepy looking I'd hope and no one tried to make us leave fortunately because it was hella fun! 

It is a bit out of the way if you don't live in the area and not exactly easy to find. But do your research on Yelp and you'll know exactly where it is. 

Me and my friend both forgot to bring cardboard, but there's a lot of pieces surrounding the slides so no worries. 

And RE: the lady who yells at people, I'm so glad she didn't yell at us because I think we were definitely louder than the kids lol.
author: Constance C.

description:
Grab a piece of cardboard and slide down these concrete slide! Its one of SF's best kept secrets -- hidden and something only the locals know about. 

I came here at night and slid down these slides! It was so much fun. Its a great bonding experience of when you want to just have fun with someone! 

Its located in between homes, so definitely come here before its gets too late at night to do this! Its fun for all ages, friends, and dates! I ruined my brown boots here, but going down the slides multiple times was definitely worth it!
author: Erin M.

description: A lovey little secret park with huge cement slides! They're only opened until 5pm though and not opened Mondays
author: Liz S.

description:
Have those things been waxed or oiled down yet?

I've been waiting patiently to go back there with my crazy carpet!   

MUAHAHAHA............!!

(Ladies, don't try the slides if you're wearing a skirt. You're welcome.)
author: Margie B.

description:
So so glad that I finally dragged my fiance here - we had a blast! It was much like being back in golden gate park as a kid sliding down the ones there, but much more hidden so it makes you feel like you've come into a secret.

Much like Kristin M's review, watch out for bitchy neighbors. I'm sorry - it's 4th of july at 2pm in the afternoon. there's kids here - do you really think laughter is that bad of a noise? You're the one who moved next door to a park, so shove it.

Anyway. Go. bring cardboard. throw some sand down the slide beforehand and go.
author: laura f.

description:
Bar-kuh at-tah Adonia el-lo-hey-nu me-lkeh ha-'o-lam a-sher kid-de-sha-nu be-mits-vo-tav le-hadlik ner shell Seward Street Slides.

Blessed are you Lord Our God king of the Universe who sanctified with his commandments and commanded us to go down the Seward Street Slides. 

God we thank you for this blessing.
author: Michael S.

description: Bring some carboard and get ready to fly ! These slides are great for the kids and big kids as well.
author: Carlos G.

description:
This itty-bitty park is a ginormous amount fun... just beware of the crazy aproned wicked witch of the west!  She comes out and tries to shame you our of their 'community' park and then if that doesn't  work, threatens to call the cops.  This is total b.s..  It's a public park and our tax monies support it.  We are welcome there, as is anyone else before dark, as the sign says.  

**Warning: You may catch air and be prepared for a fast landing!**

We went on a weekend afternoon but there was only 2 families with 3-4 kids there.  We only did the slides for @ 20 minutes but it was fun to watch the kids and enjoy the amazing view on the hill top above the park (definitely worth the hike up there).  We were gonna stay longer, just to smit the wicked witch but then figured she wasn't worth our energy... we had a good day and went on to our next stop.  It's funny, I think she thought we were a buncha hooligans but we were 2 computer engineers, 1 elementary teacher, 1 media HR director, and another couple of semi-professionals.  She was rude and we were polite and that made her mad...

I'd definitely do back, just don't go expecting a park with swings and such, it's only a narrow park between housing complexs... slides only.

See ya there! :)
author: Susan D.

description:
Im lucky to have Ruggy as a friend, otherwise I probably would have never even heard of these slides.
In the middle of a normal neighborhood lies this awesome little gem.
Two concrete slides are so fun, its worth the walk up the damn hill.
Probably a good idea to wear jeans.
author: Noel J.

description:
My Mom used to take my brothers and I here when we were little tykes!!!!

It's much larger when you're a kid, of course and the concrete didn't hurt.

LOVE this nostalgic place. It really should be open for adults without kids.
Such discrimination. Why can't adults be kids too?
I don't ever want to grow up.
author: Athena S.

description:
Awesome slides-just the same as when I went there as a kid. But there were no crazy ladies way back then. What has happened to SF?

Something I thought of AFTER the crazy ladies finally got out of my face and left: point to the park rules sign and tell them they aren't allowed in the park without kids and they need to leave. 

Tons of fun for kids and adults (with kids...). Great slides-a hidden gem!
author: Megan C.

description: I'll give it five stars because it LOOKS fun to slide down, but the downer is that they  closed the slide by putting up yellow iron gates all along it, so it's hard to enjoy yourself... especially if you're a tall person like me. Bummer. Here's to hoping that the close was only temporary!
author: Jess N.

description:
My really good friend actually had her first date here with her now husband! It is honestly so much fun. Who knew that concrete stairs existed in the middle of SF.

Make sure to bring cardboard or plastic trays to slide down. Otherwise it will hurt and you will get bruises. Also this place closes at 5:00pm so make sure to get there beforehand. Also to get to the top walk up the left of the stairs not the right. You have to be mentally prepared...

All in all a good sunday afternoon experience.
author: Shruti C.

description: These slides were SO much fun! Safe for adults and kids. Definitely bring your own cardboard. One that is waxy on one side is best so you can slide easier/faster :)
author: Gloria M.

description:
A really cool place to spend an afternoon! Just be a aware that the park sign says that's it's open from sunrise to sunset while the actual slide apparently is open from 9 to 5.

We were there at 6pm and after a couple of times going down shrieking with delight, a woman wanders over and stands by to watch. After a moment, she asks us if we're wondering why she was there. We said, no and she begins to tell us that all the screaming is terrifying to her and that the slide closed at 5pm. We said that we would stop screaming and she was satisfied and said that we were the most polite people she had encountered in a while! Such a party pooper!!!

But beware! At the top of the slide there was another woman glaring at us over the top of her fence. Even when we all stared at her, she held her ground! She is horrible!

Overall it's an awesome slide and there is plenty of cardboard at the base of the slide for anyone to use! It's really fun and worth seeking out!

This place deserves four stars, but because of the terrible fun-sucking neighbors, I'm giving it three.
author: Dina I.

description: CLOSED - has been for over a year - so any review in 2012 or 2013 is written by a poser or a jackhole who enjoys setting people up for disappointment -
author: Debi B.

description:
Sleeves.  So necessary.. I got slide-burn on my shoulder, which at least for the first night was as sensitive as a fresh tattoo.  Getting better now though, thanks for asking.

Went on a mild January Sunday afternoon, tank top weather, natch.  There were a few kids and their families, and they were more than happy to share the park with some child-at-heart adults.  There are plenty of boxes there, so don't worry too much about bringing your own.  Sand is no myth.. pretty sure that's how I ended up skinning my shoulder.  All in the name of funsies!!!
author: Christie C.

description:
enjoy the slides with children
and if the crazy ass lady next door comes into the park- WITHOUT children - call the police on her!!
Be sure you VIDEO her yelling and screaming and entering the park
( since technically - she is not allowed in the park-she has no kids with her !!! )
Be sure to show the police that when they arrive
Just obey the park rules and times you are supposed to be there
author: Pug P.

description: I could not believe 2 long curvy mini sorta luge like slides in the middle of a SF neighborhood...  Lil kids can catch fat air after the middle bumpy part.  I had fun and I am a 45 year old woman, but I only went once.  Watching my nephew race other kids was cool.  But I wondered if the nearby residents were napping or quietly reading a book on a lazy Sunday, all the while slide goers were whoopin, hollerin and screaming at the top of their lungs.
author: Riss R.

description:
Ok, it's really cool that these slides exist.  Such a random location, and very atypical playground equipment for this country.  Because they are made of concrete.  And yes, there is a risk of getting hurt!  

I went down 4 times.  3/4 were quick and fun and I was fine.  The third time was the only time I used cardboard, and I thought I should go down sitting up.  Well there's a turn in the slide, and at that turn, even though I was trying to keep my arms tucked in one caught on the side of the slide and caused a really nasty scrape/burn all along my inner arm.  It still stings badly right now, two hours later.  

So pro tip - especially if you're on cardboard, make sure to keep your arms in at all times.  I'm surprised I don't see other reviews about people getting hurt, because a father who was sliding with his kid right after us also scraped his elbow.  

I know it's not the slide's fault, but I could have done without the wounds.  Would give 3.5 stars.  Maybe I'll knock it up to a 4 at some point when I'm not hurting.
author: Danna G.

description:
I am a little late in writing this review.  We were there on 2/15/10.  We are going back again tomorrow, which my posting that may or may not be a good thing...  

First, the slides are AWESOME.  A W E S O M E. They are way faster then the ones at the Koret Children's center, and the kids have a blast riding them.  

We didn't need carboard, the sealent on the slides made them slippery enough.  We played for a good hour and a half and afterwards all 4 kids were exhausted (thank you big steep stairs!)

I love this park, and I love the simplicity of the idea behind it. I wish more parks had something like this.  It's incredible and such a treat.  It was nice to see how clean the area is, and that people have respect for keeping it clean.

Now onto the other part (note this is not affecting my rating of the awesomeness of the slides.

A woman came out of her house, and introduced herself to me and my friend while we were watching the kids, as the Seward Witch noted on Yelp.  She was 7 ways from bent out of shape that we were there, in the middle of the day (it was around 3:30)  with children.  

I listened to her rant and rave about how people keep her up all night on the slides and how she's lived there for 40 years and how she can't sleep.  ever.  I then in my calmest voice tried to tell her, that it was 3:30 in the afternoon (pointing at rules sign as I spoke) that we were infact here during park hours, that we were infact there WITH KIDS and that there really wasn't anything I could do to help her.  Heck the kids weren't even that loud. 

Her complaining was louder then the kids that were playing. I mentioned that to her (she didn't seem to like that)   and then she went on a rant about how popular the slides are and how everyone uses them, and I just agreed that they were great slides.

There are no signs that say you must be a resident to play there, and it's a public park.  My advice to others coming to check out the slides of awesomeness: 

Follow the park rules:  sunrise to sunset
have a kid (or 4) with you.  I believe one of the rules  on the sign is that adults must be accompanied by children.  
have fun, but have respect.
author: Samanta V.

description: "Super fun spot, cool concrete slides. Bring small boxes or 6-pack folded boxes to ride down on. Fun little gem in the Castro"
author: Melyssa V.

description: Yippee!!!!!  We came here last summer because of yelp, and my family and I loved it!  We were only here for about 20 minutes, and that's really all you need.  Bring cardboard and your camera.  This is a must-do in San Fran!
author: Leddee H.

description:
I have so many fond/terrifying memories of these slides, from literally flying through the air as a child, to drunkenly sliding in my high school years. I just can't express how much sliding can make a day, it really is just the connection to childhood you crave once in awhile. 
I of course bring  my trusted plastic tray, but if you can spare a cookie sheet boy will you fly! There is cardboard there, just be sure it hasn't rained or fog rained recently, because then that stuff is gross...as in, don't touch!
Do be nice to the neighbors and don't scream WEEEEEEE!!!! all the way down, especially if you are sliding after 5pm....actually, just don't do it...slide by day.
author: Bianca L.

description:
One of the bestest, dopiest, coolest, free things to do in Es Ef. That is all.

okay...one more thing: waxed cardboard seriously flies.
author: milo a.

description: As a 67 year old grandma who had an absolute BLAST with my grandsons this tops my list of must do.  Actually had a kid follow me down and do a somersault over the top of me.  FUNNY AND I  lived to tell about it.
author: Cathie S.

description:
Hi guys! I stopped writing reviews for a little while, but I'm going to write this one because it's important to me.

I live right next to the slides. I also live right next to the guy deemed "ZZ Top" by the reviewers who wrote about him earlier, and let me tell you, he's famous around these neck of the woods for being a bit of a grump. He HATES the sound of people having fun: I once heard him yelling out his window at kids who were blowing a whistle or something.

It was noon when he yelled.

As a neighbor to the slides, I also hear people yelling at 1 in the morning sometimes. That's pretty obnoxious, so if you're going to come here at that time, just be quiet. That's all, just be respectful.
 
However, screw the people who yell at you for being here past 5pm. If you wanna blow off a bit of steam after work by sliding down some concrete slides, go right ahead, I like listening to people having a good time. It makes me smile. In fact, I am issuing a call to arms: come here anytime before 8pm and yell to your hearts content. You shouldn't be terrorized for having a bit of fun. It's a sleepy neighborhood, I welcome you.
author: Adam M.

description:
Yes! Yes! Yes! Yes! Yes! You must go to the Seward Street Slides, they are so much fun! I dragged my friends up there these weekend and we had such a blast! We were running up and sliding back down, cracking up like we were 5 years old. I may have hurt myself, bent my keys and ripped my favorite jacket but I have no regrets!

This is an SF gem everyone should experience!

Tip: The slide on the left (if you are at the top looking down) is way faster than the one on the right. If you forget cardboard go to Cala on 18th and Castro and ask,  they are used to it by now.
author: Javier B.

description: Good free fun! I'm not kidding when I say you go FAST on these slides. These are not your local Chuck E Cheese's slides, you catch some good air. Also, watch out on the landing; don't be surprise if you eat sh** at the end. Just brush your knees/butt off and go again!
author: Cindy A.

description:
So. Much. Fun!

Bring some cardboard and your inner-child(or a real child). Hot metal slide will burn the skin right off your arm as you whiz down to the sandy below~
author: S ..

description:
There are certain things that can instantly take you back to your childhood. Ice cream truck music, Saturday morning cartoons, GI Joe, footy pajamas, and slides. There's that moment when you're sitting at the top of a slide where the expectation of what's about to happen is only matched by the exhilaration from actually going down the slide. As an adult, you rarely get the opportunity to be a kid. Luckily, these slides exist. I know they're supposed to be for kids, but c'mon, they're irresistible. And they're not kid-sized slides. There's actually a split second where you do a mental check to make sure you have health insurance. OK, it's not double black-diamond steep, but it's long and steep enough to be a lot of fun. 

They're a bit hard to find, but that's probably for the better, otherwise you'd have office workers coming here during their lunch breaks, people taking cuts, dresses being torn, just general bedlam. If there are kids here, I try to do a couple quick runs and give them what's rightfully theirs. If there aren't any kids there, well, the slide on the left is faster, and there's usually a stack of cardboard to ride down on. Just sayin'.
author: Saunders C.

description:
The afternoon of our Anchor Brewery tour, after brown bagging 40s in Dolores Park and having ice cream at Bi-rite, we decided to make our somewhat drunken hike to the Seward Street Slides. 

It's a bit strange that they're in the middle of a neighborhood, not actually in a park, sandwiched in between two houses that I'm sure get more than their fair share of boisterous drunks at 2am. Luckily, we were there around 4pm, probably before they even got home from work.

The slides were fun, but not nearly as awesome as the really big cement slide in Cordornices park in Berkeley. But at this park, there are two slides so you can race each other.

Be sure to bring cardboard to fly down the slide at lightening speeds and try not to be too loud for the neighbors past 9pm.
author: Stephanie H.

description: Yet another reason why I love SF...you can be a kid as a grown up. The Seward Slides prove it. After making a long trek from the Mission up the hill to Seward street we felt like we had finally earned a little fun. The only problem was they looked kinda steep and a bit scary. We figured we took the time to walk up the hill, we might as well go for broke and boy am I happy we did. It's like riding down a concrete luge with a piece of cardboard. We were had quite a short rush but it's definitely a lot of fun. Go before it starts raining. Make sure you don't wear brand new jeans though...it kinda spoils the fun.
author: Amy J.

description: This was AWESOME!!!  I heard about the slides and then checked out yelp... I was a little nervous about the witches and warned the group I was walking with to just ignore them or to kill them with kindness.  But the witches were a no show, so we got to have lots of fun without them!  I have to say, I was the teensiest bit disappointed.  Seems that dealing with the crazy ladies might be part of the Seward Street Slides Experience!  I didn't get bruised or scraped or dirty at all!  It was GREAT!
author: Michael H.

description: Well we went there on a Monday and kids were so disappointed to find out it was CLOSED. Apparently it is closed on Mondays and the slides had bars on them. The slides did look like they would have been a lot of fun. So I'm knocking one star for not being open on a Monday and another star for no parking or signage. If you are looking for a large sign with the park name - it doesn't exist. And the one man we saw walking into his house had no idea these slides were even there or at least acted like he didn't know. Also there is no parking as it is on one of those tiny side streets in SF.
author: Esella S.

description:
Cool Runnings mon!!!

The best Jamaican bobsled team fun I've had at a playground yet and a great way to kill time in the area.
 
Some words of advice though, if you don't feel like leaving a memento of skin chunks on the slide or feel like burning holes into the ass of your best pants, hold onto the cardboard (bring your own, germaphobes) and keep your arms & legs up & in while you go down. Go down the right side...it does seem faster & more fun!
Cheeeehoo boyee!!
author: Greasybones V.

description:
How have I lived here for 3 years and still have never been here until this past week?! Craziness.

I absolutely loved the slides, and make sure to bring your cardboard!!
author: Lauren S.

description:
I want to start this review by stating that it's not the slide's fault.  I'm sure the slide itself deserves 5 stars, but the experience was so horrific for us, we left completely traumatized, thus the 1 star.

Important facts to note:
It was my friend's B-day.  
We're all 30 and 40 somethings.
It was 5:30pm.
Not a one of us had been drinking.

We were standing in a small group at the base of the slides waiting for more friends to arrive (5 waiting for 7 more) and were talking quietly amongst ourselves. We planned to each take a slide and then head off for our dinner reservations--our motivation was to briefly recapture our youth.  The youth we recaptured, however, was the youth of Rumpelstiltskin and the Troll.

Disguised as a fellow slider, a small women came up to our group asking if we were *her group*.  We politely said that we were not, we were just waiting for some friends, and then like someone flipped a switch, she started SCREAMING at the top of her lungs *Get the FUCK out of here!! The park is CLOSED!!!* waving her hands around trying to be intimidating.  

At first her demeanor was so ludicrous we thought she was joking, and we all laughed nervously.  She continued to yell demeaning things at us, calling us stupid and unattractive (what??), while we tried to explain that it was a B-day party, we only planned on being there a short time, and we had been almost silent up until that point.  The noise her tizzy was making was easily thrice as loud as our whole group.  

And did I mention that it was FIVE THIRTY IN THE AFTERNOON ON A SATURDAY????

She kept saying over and over that she *wasn't special* (which I guess was meant to imply that we thought we were for wanting to slide??) and for the most part wasn't very coherent.

When we realized she wasn't kidding, as she threatened to call the cops and literally lunged at us, we came back with a few retorts--*It's 5:30 on a Sat--are the neighbors even home now?*, *This is a public park*, and *You're the one that bought property next to a slide*, to which she then completely came unglued pointing to all the surrounding houses while foaming at the mouth, asking us if we were BLIND or just STUPID and hadn't we noticed the signs.  

We allowed ourselves to be chased out not because we thought we were wrong (in fact, we were quite respectful and aware of the neighbors and had no intention of being disruptive) but because she was so completely irate and bizarre acting she put a huge downer on our evening and we just wanted to get away.

Had this not been a celebratory occasion and had we not had dinner reservations in short order, we might have waited her out, let her call the cops to see how long they took to get there.  I'm sure busting over to diamond heights to *save* the resident of a multi-million dollar house from a group of respectful middle aged sliders is right up there on their list of emergencies.

Again, had she asked us nicely or even approached us in ANY reasonable fashion, we would have dutifully complied.  We all live in the city and know what it's like when *that guy* is drunk outside our apt at 3am and we're trying to sleep.  Her demeanor, however, was so reprehensible that I felt no compassion for her or her situation at all--especially since we weren't drinking, loud OR disruptive, and again, it was late afternoon, not 2am.

Advice to anyone going there in the future--should you meet the troll, DO NOT ENGAGE.  Absolutely ignore her--give her no ammo to respond to, and continue on with your business. Turn your back on her, act as if she's not there--any exchange will just fuel her self righteous indignation.  The chance that the cops will get there before you've had your slide is slim to none, and if you slide quietly and respectfully, there should be no problem.

Because she is completely irrational and highly theatrical she is a bit scary, but I'm sure she knows that to touch is to be arrested.  
Let her work herself into a froth, spread bad energy and display what an unhappy person she is, but don't give her any more reason to hate.

If you're really feeling belligerent and you've been scolded @ the slides before, why not take the letter of the law seriously and go slide at dawn?  If the park really is closed from dusk till dawn, who's to stop the 5:30am sliders?  

Doesn't a benevolent approach to fellow San Franciscans make for better community relations that screaming and belittling?  All this neighbor did last night was make a dozen new enemies.

The icing on the cake:  As she stomped back to her house, we saw that she didn't even live in a house that bordered the slide--she was 2 houses away!!
CRAZY!
author: D C.

description:
The belated 21st birthday adventure continued here with Sam M. (http://www.yelp.com/biz/seward-street-slides-san-francisco#hrid:6wmXA5IR3Yvbvxpef4HaMA) and Adam B.

We arrived slightly drunk, mostly winded though after taking a wrong hill here or there, and were slightly put off at first by the presence of children (goodness forbid) and the large signs announcing "No adults unless accompanied by children".

But it turned out to be cool actually.  The slides are just simply concrete undulating ramps that you negotiate with cardboard (like, from a box).  Definitely take the slide with your hands up.  These slides can also be a great way to break in a pair of jeans, too.  Like Sam said, a sleeping bag provides an awesome ride.  Sam shared a sleeping bag with a twelve year old ("He said he was 14...").

And it was here that we picked up the word of the night.  The oldest kid, who was totally only 12, was berating his younger foster sister, and concluded his argument with "Don't be such a pussy!"  We were in titters for the rest of the night.
author: Jeremy K.

description:
Over 300 reviews? What have I got to say that hasn't been said before. 

Beware the crazy lady who lives near the bottom. She was agressive and NASTY when she confronted me and 10 of my friends who were gathering for a birthday party around 6pm (just dark).

She came up and asked politely "Are you part of my group? (laughter) Oh, we're in a different group? (laugher)"

Then an abrupt change...

"!!!OK GET THE F*** OUT!! NOW!!! I'VE CALLED THE POLICE!!"

Rational conversation bounced right off her and she insulted everyone who tried to talk to her, even lunged at my friend who tried to take a picture of her (we were worried at that point).

Anyway, the slides are cool. The crazy witch-troll, apparently not so much.

I suppose I can understand when people are doing this constantly near your house... maybe? I don't know, she seemed over-the-top angry. Almost like she ENJOYED it. As if it were her only social contact or something. Oh well, enough postulating. 

Just go before it gets dark or she'll GETCHA!
author: David Z.

description: We saunter up, see a convenient pile of flattened cardboard toboggans / boxes conveniently placed just at our right: not an adult in sight. It's a doozy -- steep enough to make you wish you had more butt, just this one time...
author: David S.

description:
Thank you Yelp for showing me this San Francisco gem.

My boyfriend and I stumbled over here after some Friday night fun. I can't say I would ever bring my children here, but my slightly intoxicated free flowing body? Anytime!

Parking isn't the best (like you should be driving if you go here drunk). The pictures will be priceless. When we went there was plenty of cardboard lying on the ground from past guests. I recommend bringing a piece or wearing clothes you can possibly snag.

Let's go cement louge!!!
author: Aubrey W.

description: Went during the normal hours posted, but unfortunately there were locked barriers in place so couldn't try this one out. If there weren't any barriers, I admit I would've had wanted to experience for myself what it would've been like, but perhaps it just wasn't meant to be that day.  Thought it was funny how the sign said, "No adults unless accompanied by children" ;-)  At least now my friends and I know exactly where this is at and what it actually looks like - we all expected to see something else entirely different, but if anything, this could be seen as one more thing crossed off the list of things to see/do in SF.
author: Kahanalei M.

description:
This was the funnest thing EVER. I will definitely go back the next time I'm in SF. We were at the park on Saturday afternoon. Some other families were there enjoying the slides, and we all had fun playing together. 

No sign of angry neighbors. I can see where it could be aggravating as we knew we were going the right direction from the sound of shrieking and laughing from waaay down Seward Street. The slides are so fun that you just can't help letting out a little yell while you're riding!! At night that would get old, fast! There is a sign that clearly states the hours and "rules" for the park. Follow 'em and don't be the jerk that ruins things for everyone else.

There were plenty of flattened boxes at the park so no need to BYO. Bring your camera and a smile, and have fun sliding!
author: Jen F.

description:
My butt has marked this cement slide since I was a wittle, wittle girl.  Their was never a shortage of cardboard and the momentum is enough that you wish the slide would go a little bit longer. Just make sure their is some sand on the slide or you'll find yourself stuck in the middle of it.  No worries though...just drag yourself down towards the end or just simply get up and walk down towards the end. 
Ahh memories at this lovely place.
author: Blue S.

description: I haven't gone again...but I heard the slides are back in operation! Even though the slides were scratched up so they were no longer smooth rides, the persistence of sliders sliding down the scratched up slides eventually wore down the scratches! Now it's all gooood...
author: Margaret R.

description: So much fun! In the mini park. And there's cardboard in the recycling bin if you need some.
author: Samantha M.

description:
This is the most fun i've had in San Francisco. And can you believe it's a lesser known secret location, which means many people have lived in San Francisco for years without knowing of its existence. 

Everyone young and old needs to experience these slides. Take your cardboard box, or just take yourself in a pair of pants you dont care about, and wiz down those slides to release your inner child.  And don't forget the most important thing... SCREAM at the top of your lungs !!!

Yelp's address says they're located on the corner of Douglass and Seward Street, but they're actually located in a garden b/t Corwin and Seward (the Corwin Street Community Gardens to be specific), near Kite Hill. 

However beware of the neighbours. As the reviews below point out, the neighbours are unreasonable and slightly psychotic, yelling and threatening to call the cops. They really make you feel like a bad person. And like the reviewer below, it was around 5pm on a sunday when we were set upon by the nasty neighbours.  

Plus these slides seem too dangerous for children. As an adult i was so scared i watched everyone else go down first before even daring to attempt it myself. So don't fall for the neighbours' mantra that the slides are only for kids. Though it makes sense they'd say that, since they are psychotic, maybe they want to see children get hurt. 

I dont know what is wrong with the locals, but my advice is to ignore them and dont argue with them. They've probably called the cops so many times that the cops don't pay attention anymore

Have fun fun fun !!
author: Belle C.

description: Weeeeeeeeeeeeee!
author: Ruggy J.

description:
This is by far one of my favorite spots in San Francisco. I take anyone who visits from out of town here. Even my New York friends, often reticent to believe anything could ever rival glory child of the East have left proclaiming "I want to live HERE!"

I only give it 4 stars, because I have twice now had run-ins with the "so lucky to be homeowners in San Francisco" stick up the bum neighbors who, despite knowing what their owned Victorians sit next to, love to threaten to call the police on people laughing or squealing on the slides. The first instance involved one lady yelling at my 54 year old father and his wife for being too loud. Thanks, Miss Marple. You seem coo-ka-loo.
The last instance happened last night when I went with a group as a stop for a 31st birthday party and a guy came out screaming at us at 5pm on a Sunday. Ol' ZZ Top proceeded to berate us as people and threaten to call the police. Too late. Miss Marple was already on TWO DIFFERENT phones with the police and she wanted us to know it.

I could understand if we had been there at 10pm, midnight, 4am, but it was still daylight and it wasn't even dinner time. When told that he was ruining a birthday party he said "I don't care." Thanks ZZ Top. Who's wearing nice shoes and speaking calmly and who might possibly be hiding a squirrel in their facial hair in this situation?

The neighbors are jerks. And for some reason they think that the SF PD is going to actually do something about a group of well-dressed adults having a nice time on some slides that are WAY too dangerous for children.

So beware of ZZ Top and Miss Marple. Otherwise, the slides are the best thing ever.
author: Michael B.

description:
Absolutely the most fun I've ever had at a public park! My five year old son and I are always searching for cheap ways to have a blast, and yesterday we found the ultimate. I have to admit, however, that the lady who lives in the house next to the slides nearly ruined our day of fun. She yelled at me (she's not exactly the quiet type) for about ten minutes straight, AFTER my son and I apologized for screaming during his first time down the slide, and AFTER I told her that we would be quiet for the remainder of our visit.. She would not quit yelling at me, and she insulted my intelligence and capabilities as a mother, saying that I should be "aware of my surroundings," and "control my child." I chose to not let any of this get to me, and she finally quit yelling at me after she realized we weren't actually making ANY noise at all, but merely going down the slides in total silence (still fun!)
A friendly couple and their three children showed up, and my son started talking and playing with those kids, and the lady came out again, and this time, started turning purple in the face and screaming. She called the police, and had the father of the three kids arrested (for whatever reason, she lied, because he did nothing wrong). 
Here is some advice: If you go, take a tray (like the ones at Mc Donald's, you can find them at dollar stores) because they help you slide faster than cardboard, try to be quiet, and call the police to have the psychotic lady arrested for harassment the second she tries to intimidate you. She is a very mean, lying bully. The laughter of children hurts her ears, and that is a sad, sad thing. Let's not let people like her ruin our fun. In my opinion, the world needs more fun places like the Seward Street Slides. Whoever built them was brilliant!
author: Caroline M.

description:
This was my favorite place to take friends, visitors and couchsurfers when I lived in SF. I've even met people at this park that I made friends with. It used to be a little less crowded, and we spent some nights hanging out here before night time became off limits. I will always look fondly upon my slide days...ah, youth! 

Just don't compete with little kids, and make sure you don't slide into one.
author: Lauren R.

description:
Better than the slides at the Children's Playground!

So fun...you can almost get a citation from the cops!

When I arrived at the slides, I watched this one kid fly down the slides on wax paper and was thisclose to cracking his head.  Then I KNEW I had to try it!  The slides are short but mighty fast.  The turn will surprise you!  I let out a shriek and almost peed in my pants the first time I went down.  So satisfying...

Unfortunately, someone called the cops and we got kicked out of the playgroud.  BOO!!!
author: Helen V.

description:
How many times have I told the tale of the Concrete Slides just to be dismissed as a crazy drunk (sometimes true)? I speak of the steep start, the abrupt shot to the left and the final drop before being spit onto the filthy, cardboard remnent laden sand pit at the bottom. 

OH SWEET JOY OF A SLIDE! 

* Bring waxed cardboard for a "more extreme" ride...

I would also want to stress respecting this place and not bringing alcohol and glass and trash up here. Keep it clean... And yeah, someone always gets hurt... So, thats happend.

A
author: A W.

description:
Talk about an adrenaline rush.

Keep your arms tucked inside your cardboard luge. I left with a scrape.

My friend landed on the sand pit on his behind. There was something funky in it (like dog piss or droppings), so try landing on your feet or else you might leave smelling like poo.
author: Valerie L.

description: Yes - I'm just a BIG kid at Heart.  I LOVE this place.
author: Christine P.

description: Fun and free - two words that barely coexist these days. Get your own cardbox for your bottom or take one from the park itself. How can you go wrong? My 10&8 year old had a great time, free of iPods, iPads, Disney princesses and pushy ads. Top it all off by eating at one the many area restaurants.
author: Ani M.

description:
This is my very first review.  And I am SAD that it is a negative review.  This has been the greatest man-made object ever built in San Francisco.  Yet, some people, I do not know who (lets refer to these people as "dreamkillers"), have decided to destroy what was once great.

There is now a line of sanded destruction going down the middle of both slides.  It is now slower than molasses rolling down a tree.  Not to mention, the slide now sands and rubs your butt like a grater on cheese.

Tragic..just tragic.  I can only say that I am glad I have experienced the slide before the "dreamkillers" came and took my only place of joy away.

I am sorry for all who missed out, but know the urban legend of a slide tucked away in a fairy tale park was not a myth but a true story.  However, these "dreamkillers" monsters with cement destroyers came to the land of the seward street slide and took it all away.
author: Clayton A.

description:
So my husband grew up in the City and wanted to take his kids to a really cool place that he remembered from when he was a kid. 

We parked legally and enjoyed the slide at 3:30 on a Sunday afternoon. But there was a group of 20-somethings there as well who were a bit shrieky. I wouldn't even have thought anything about their noise level as it seemed reasonable to me, but there was a lady who started shouting loudly out of her home at us.  

I am only writing this review to point out two things: her window was open, and it would be easy to shut out the noise by closing it. It wasn't that loud. 

And two, it does suck that this place has gained so much notoriety from Yelp. The slides are fun and fast. Your butt will be airborne. But it's just a tiny little parklette and I think most people would get tired of crowds trekking into their local park all the time. My in-laws live across town in Bernal Heights and also have a slide between the streets like this - they're just not concrete nor are they popular on Yelp. There are more of them around the City and they are a joy to residents who need a place to blow off steam in their own neighborhood. It's a shame people have to get contentious about it. I can definitely see both sides.
author: Susan K.

description:
My best friend and I stayed here for well over an hour sliding down these wonderful slides.  Yes - four full grown couples had already come and gone at separate times while we were there.  They're just that fun.

There's lots of leftover cardboard in the sand, which was great, because we took BART to SF for the day and couldn't haul boxes around with us.  Choose wisely - some of the cardboard slides better others.

This place is meant to be a playground, although I really think these are big kid (*cough* adult) slides... they're kind of dangerous-looking for the babies I saw a lot of moms bringing.  They're concrete, they're steep, and you'll catch air.  And scrape yourself (it's awesome).

If you need help finding it, what we did was go south on Castro, right on 20th, and then the street turns - literally - into Douglass.  Take the first left (Seward) and the playground will be marked by a large arch. :)

Go in the daytime, let the kids go first (it is a playground), take turns with the adults, and don't make too much noise.  Be polite and everyone will have a great time.  Oh and don't bring your dog - one lady brought hers and it peed in the sand at the bottom of the slides.  People (me) are going to fall into that sand, I don't need to fall into pee too.
author: Ellen S.

description: I keep forgetting the times this place is closed. The hours posted aren't accurate, I think. Mondays are closed and the slide closes after 5. Shame. Fun, and a typical SF thing to do if you're in the area. Beautiful houses, too.
author: Gauri V.

description:
Bad effing ass.  There are many fun things to do in "the city", but if you want something quaint, fun and free, well then find your way to the Seward Street Slides.  

Following Ellen S's directions, it's a real easy spot to find.   

It was Sunday afternoon, and there was one other family there (granted I think the parents had more fun going down the slide than the kids did).

There are 2 ways to walk up, the left side facing the slide has some steps (careful, I was in heels) and there is also just a direct steep ramp up too.

Make sure to raise your arms (not even for the fact that you go fast, but holding on will scrap up your arms for sure).  

There WERE some McDonald's plastic trays there you could use in additon to the cardboard.  I wasn't gangsta enough to use it though since I was in my heels (don't ask, I wasn't prepared for this) but my friend used it and said you actually catch AIR at a part of the slide that drops a bit.  

2 people that went before me straight up landed on their asses HARD.  I was so freaked out that would happen to me, I made sure to slow down as I was approaching the end.  

Craziness.  Want it more crazier? Smoke some herbs and you'll have a blast. :)
author: K D.

description:
BEWARE OF THE TATTLE TALE LADY!!! 

Helen V., Clayton A. and I had so much fun that the cops were called! I started wondering who I should call when I was in jail. I was also hoping they had body wash instead of soap...just in case I let one slip out of my hands. I was TERRIFIED! 

LUCKILY, the cop said she didn't want to bust us...and said we should leave before she changes her mind. I'm so glad she LET US SLIDE (no pun intended!). 

But before we got in trouble, I had the time of my life here. The slides here are faster than a water slide. Make sure to put your feet down at the end to slow down...or else you are going to fly off and EAT IT! 

According to Clayton A. and Margaret R....the slides have been ruined by the "dreamkillers". Probably ruined by the TATTLE TALE LADY...damn her!
author: Allan M.

description:
Great fun, however, the lady who lives next door is crazy. My 7 year old and my 5 year old nephew were playing on the slides all by themselves at 2 in the afternoon on a Tuesday...in the middle of summer, and she yelled at them at the top of her lungs to "SHUT THE FUCK UP!!!"-Yes to a five and seven year old!  I said back to her, not to yell or cuss at them, they are children. Which caused a lot of her screaming and yelling at me. So I told her that if the kids are too loud, call the police and make a report instead of screaming at people. Did that stop her? Nope. So then she got her friend to come out and try to intimidate us by taking photos, I told her to stop taking photos of the kids. "I have a right to take photos of children in a park." "Not without parent permission, and the rules here say no adults without children....you are an adult here without children taking photos of little kids. YOU are breaking the law."  She then left and said she would call the police. I said, "Go do that. I would love to see you call the police on a five year old for making noise in a public park in the middle of the day." "Well, I have a picture of you!!" I said, "I'm proud of you...now since you are here without children you may go now." (I'm supposed to be scared because she got a picture of me sitting on a park bench?) Then she said, "Its not appropriate for kids to be loud in public!!!" I said, "Yes, it is totally appropriate for kids to be noisy on a public playground. That's what a playground is for." I then pointed to rule number 2 (no adults without children)...and she left. Then more parents came and got to see the two crazies in action. Screaming at little kids at 2 in the afternoon for laughing. She came back and yelled at some poor lady because she was sitting on a park bench with her dog. "NO DOGS ALLOWED IN THE PARK!! DIDN'T YOU SEE THE SIGN???!" The lady politely said, "no i didn't." then the crazy lady while taking pictures of her tried to show her where it says that...turns out she couldn't find it because the sign didn't exist. Then video taped people sitting on benches.They ignored, and then laughed at her and and the other crazy lady when she left. 
So if you:
-come to the park during park hours
-have kids with you
Tell the crazy ladies to quit yelling and they call the police if they are concerned about the noise. Then ignore. Thats what we did, and the kids had a grand time, and they completely ignored the witch next door. If the lady starts taking pictures of kids, call 911 to report an adult alone in the park is taking pictures of little kids when parents have asked her to stop.
author: Catherine A.

description: Tucked away in a quiet neighborhood, the Seward Street Slides is a perfect example of why San Francisco rocks!  From gathering cardboard off a random street, to sliding down the slides surrounded by kids, my bf & I had a blast.  Beware though, if you use wax paper, you better be prepared for some serious speed! In fact, you better be wearing long sleeves.  I got a pretty gnarly battle wound :p  Thank you Yelpsters for this amazing find!
author: Lai T.

description:
This place is absolutely wonderful.  It's free and AWESOME, which is hard to find in this expensive city.  I went with a friend after a few drinks, and I flew down that thing so fast, that I caught some air after the bump, and then landed straight on my tailbone, causing a bruise that lasted for several weeks.  Ouch, right? TOTALLY WORTH IT.

As for the nice folks living in the area: sorry, but hell, you know you're living in one of the most desirable neighborhoods in SF, right?  So, give us poor assholes a break when we seek out free entertainment.
author: danielle p.

description:
fun, free.

It's fun, not dangerous...I guess i expected it to be bigger, but would be a great place to take your kids for some quick cheap fun.

there was cardboard left there when I was there, but actually was faster without it.  Wax paper may help.
author: John B.

description: I seem to never be able to go during the day (when the slides are open) always at night!!! But its fun as well, granted a small part of the slide is gated off so people cant kill themselves on the slides while there are no people around. Point is its a fun place to go!
author: Nina M.

description:
We went on Christmas day. A little boy looked at me and said, ' You will go so fast your bottom will smoke'. I had to laugh. Sure enough, when i got off, the cardboard smelled like smoke. It was caused by the friction of the sand someone cemented to the slide. Fortunately most of the sand had worn off from the month before, and we were able to catch good speed. Was it the evil troll lady everyone writes about who tried to destroy all the fun? Alas, the slides are nearly to their original state :)
Awesome Time- You have to go!
author: SF U.

description:
Awesome. 

I recommend going down lying on your stomach on the right hand side (when you are facing downard) for the best experience.  I wanted to try face first but I am thirty and tweaked my back on like my 5th run.

I hear plastic trays and cookie trays increase speed?  Im there!

What was funny was this hipster in front of us was with his girlfriend and we were all waiting for him to come down, then we just hear "im having troubles with the slide.." and he comes down and they leave, probably on their fixies off into the mission.  Funny hipsters.
author: Richard N.

description: Yeah, I definitely did this. They're kinda hard to find, but if you make it in the general direction and ask a family/kids nearby, they'll probably help direct you. We brought our own cardboard, but I think there would have been some anyway. And it was scary. I went feet first a couple times, and used the outside of my foot to kind of slow my descent until I was comfortable going faster. This isn't a whole afternoon thing - the slides are not as long as I had expected (give it a between 5 and 10 second ride) but it is worth trying out.
author: Christina K.

description:
As you get older, you find fewer and fewer things that you do that make you genuinely excited (even work becomes work after awhile). But finding this gem was one of those things that just makes your day, week, heck even your month so much better! 

A couple words of wisdom. 
First, I recommended having a beer before, during, and/or after going here. There is a great corner store at 20th St. and Castro St. that sells one pint cans with an accompanying brown sack- best $2.75 I have spent in awhile. 
Second, wear sturdy clothes and be prepared for some pain (the beer helps with this part). Shorts or pants and a shirt that you are not afraid of getting dirty are musts. 
Third, if you are having a hard time finding it, go to 20th St and Castro St (good time to get a beer) and go West (toward the ocean!) on 20th until it veers to the right. Take the first left and you are there. 

Have fun!
author: Scott J.

description: These two concrete slides hidden away in a miniature park on the tiny side street of Seward is just about the coolest find you could hope for in the city. Although I'm sure you'd go down just fine without them, sitting on a piece of cardboard makes you whip down the 20 or so foot ride faster than any slide that didn't involve water (there's usually plenty of pieces of piece of cardboard laying around where you don't have to bring one). The slides are sort of narrow so if you're a wide person you might not fit so well. As an adult I haven't had fun going down a slide since I was probably 12 so it took a lot of self control not to run back and forth going down over and over again while a group of teenagers sat there watching. There's two right beside each other so it's a great way to race your friends, just make sure you don't go too late because the park closes in the evening.
author: Matt E.

description:
oh yes.

You must go. Good simple fun.

As for the sign that reads "No Adults Allowed Unless Accompanied By Children", well, i think they actually meant to say "This Is More Fun When Not Sober." (and it's true)

Enjoy
author: Paul B.

description:
Being unemployed has it's perks. When else could I check out a concrete slide in the middle of a secluded neighborhood in Noe Valley on a beautiful Wednesday afternoon? 

I will definitely be back....cardboard or taco bell tray in hand.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Extremely rewarding.

My friend and I were wondering where to go after eating lunch at Thailand Restaurant across from the Castro Theatre and she suggested the Slides. I was a bit skeptical until I Yelped this, and boy am I glad I did.

We took the 24 for one stop and got off to sit on a bench to settle a water spill in her bag. Within minutes, we found an empty Yamaha bike rack box. We hit the jackpot and was walking by Eureka Street (hmm...). Anyway, we carried the box up hills to reach the mini park. The kids there stared at our brand new box in envy. We split the box in two using keys, fingers, fists, and force. And we were off to anti-gravity central! Seriously though, halfway down, you'll feel like you are off the cement like those log rides at amusement parks. Be sure to have a long piece of cardboard that extends from feet to butt because you want to protect yourself the whole way. This can cause some deep cuts in your designer jeans/clothes/shoes/socks/undergarments. 

I think it's better to keep your arms tucked in rather than in the air for a full throttle experience. The little girl with her younger brother there kept bringing sand up and dumping it down the slide. I'm not sure if it makes the cardboard go down faster but I don't think it has any effect. She did say the left slide is faster than the right slide but I think it varies. 

Luckily we didn't encounter the crazy neighbor(s) that were mentioned by unfortunate Yelpers! We did get greeted by a friendly dog that I am going to assume is owned by one of the neighbors. He really liked my A&F jeans, no joke.
author: Dominic T.

description:
The most fun I have had in a while.  Difficult to find, but worth the effort.  

And true to form, we had a run in with lady who lives next door.  She was very upset we were being too loud.  We were there on a Sunday afternoon, around 3:30, 4pm.  And we were there for probably a total of 15-20 mins, (we came to slide and then we left.)  As she shouted at us from her window several times, I wonder if HER neighbors were sick of hearing her yell at US.

It's not my fault your beautiful million dollar home is next to those SUPER fun slides.  As we were leaving, the angry neighbor sent her poor kid out to . . . . confront us.  

I don't care though, because I had a blast and I will return!
author: Ashley P.

description:
A+ 

way worth the trek up the hill. these slides never get old.
author: bo h.

description:
THIS SLIDE IS AMAZING. 

The instant I got there some kid went down to fast and hit himself and started crying. And all I could think was "Bring it on, bitch"

Its really dangerous, ridden with pieces of cardboard, but it's so fun and amazing. Im not lightweight, but I caught some air on the middle bump. I love it. I want to go back ASAP. I need a doctor, I need a lawyer, I need a cheese sandwich. 

Admittedly, that sign about "No adults unless accompanies by children" made me feel bad :(
author: Dustin H.

description: Circled a gazillion times looking for parking, stepped in dog crap, walked UP numerous hills, it was cold, then it got hot...Totally worth it.
author: guppeee p.

description:
Careful. The secret slides have been barricaded as of this week . 

Drunks folks do pee done the slides. Just fyi. A friend late at night  (yes, he was drunk but didn't ruin the ride so to speak) went down the slides and realized he was damp and stinky from it. bleh. Also, yes, there is a very yelly lady who calls the cops. 

+* It is a fun ride (for 3 seconds). Day time.
-* -* -* -*
1) urine slide from other late night revelers?
2) yelly lady.
3) if you're wearing short sleeves, you could get a concrete burn. I have elliptical scars on both sides of my arms. 
4) cops will come if you're loud (hard not to go "WHOOOOa!" Down the slide.
author: Trinity M.

description:
Wanna impress people with your knowledge of San Francisco? Then take them to the Seward Street Slides, a hidden gem off of lovely Seward St. in the Castro. So much fun!!! Yippee!!

They have a large supply of cardboard on-hand, as well as a stash of McDonald's trays for those with a major need for speed. I like to live life in the slow lane, so I just stuck with the cardboard. (My preference for the cardboard was vindicated when a guy careened down the slide on a tray and almost ate it on the concrete at the bottom and my husband had to leap out of the way. Kind of dangerous, but funny as hell to watch!) Even with the cardboard, though, man, are these slides fast! I got some air at one point on the way down.  And, as some folks pointed out, definitely wear jeans.

Can't wait to experience the glee of these slides again very soon!
author: Rachel G.

description:
No Adults Unless Accompanied By A Child.  Those words will forever be ingrained in my mind as walk up the steep slope to the top of the slides.  I quickly take a piece of wax paper, the size of my ass and place it atop the slide.  i quickly hop onto the slide, sit on the piece of wax paper and mentally prepare myself for the quick ride down. 1-2-3 whoosh.  Down i go.  I hit the turn and i get a lot of air and my ass drops back down onto the slide right before i fly off the end of the slide.  im able to get my feet down but i end up falling to my knees.  Woohoo!! let's do it again!!

Hidden in a small park, this place is known to few.  After coming here, my ass was sore, i have a few burns from my arm rubbing against the side of the slides, and and a tweaked foot for landing funny off the slide.  Despite the pain, i would come here again in a heart beat.  Cardboard is provided, if you don't mind using dirty cardboard on in the dirt.  But if you wanna fly through the slide, you gotta use wax paper!  i felt like i was a kid again and boy was it fun!
author: Aaron G.

description:
Next time, I'm bringing some heavy duty pants! 

I rode down twice, borrowing a kid's long piece of cardboard, and managed to lightly scrape my hand while at it. My piece of advice? Just leannnn back while you're riding down. Don't hold onto your piece of cardboard like me and shake around. Lol what funnnn!
author: Sara T.

description:
Oh you marvelous slides!  Quite possibly the city's best use of concrete in a public area!  I remember when I first found out about the Seward Street slides I was 7 years old and thought them to be the coolest thing ever.    Many years later and I still love going to them.

The slides are tucked away on a small strip in a residential area between Seward and Corwin Streets.  You can enter from either side, though I like to walk downhill from Corwin because there is a very nice like garden. If you are familiar with Kite Hill, they are located a mere block away if you follow the trail off Corwin (this is a good starting point if you have difficulty locating the slides). 

You can get some real speed and real airtime on these puppies, so use a bit of caution when you go.   I once saw someone with a child in the lap go down and the poor kid hit his head during the middle jump spot. 

Now to maximize your enjoyment of the slides several things are essential 
1) CARDBOARD!  You can usually find this laying around in the sand pit at the bottom, however if you have the chance play it safe and bring your own (I've gone on a whim before and was quite bummed when I only found overused scraps).
2) WAXPAPER.  If you really want to build speed and have a frictionless ride put some wax paper underneath your cardboard.
3)....and for the truly daring...throw a handful of sand down the slide (and even a little underneath your cardboard) right before you take the plunge.  I find that this increases speed, kind of like little ball bearings.  Though some people have told me that this is bullsh*t and doesn't help at all, and also that it may erode the slides, because it will sure erode your waxpapper and cardboard quicker.   Try it once and see if it's for you.


Also...
-Be aware that it is a playground and technically adults without children are not allowed (a large sign clearly states this).  Not that this will ever stop me, but I do take it into account and I'm mindful of when children and their parents want to use it.  Be polite and considerate to other sliders of all ages.
-Try not to come at night or inebriated.   I know it's fun to go down slides drunk, but it's a very residential area and they shouldn't have to be bothered or kept up at night by the exhilarated screams.
-Wear clothes that you don't care too much about.  I've had friends tear and stain their clothing .

These slides are just so damn cool.
author: Kevin A.

description:
DO NOT SLIDE IF...

1) It's past ten at night.
2) You are wearing shorts.
3) If you are legal to vote.
4) If God has pulled the "age-of-thirty-five-rip-cord" and your hips have ballooned to the size of two small sea lions.

BECAUSE...

1) You will get the cops called on your ass.
2) You will rip the very skin off your leg bones like a bleu cheese dressing dipped chicken wing at a Niner's tailgate.
3) Duh.
4) You will be sliding into being stuck...and the slides will be your final resting place.

Obviously, someone who lives near the slides has unencrypted Wi-Fi...because I'm still there.  

FOR THE LOVE OF BABY JESUS, SEND HELP!
author: Kristina R.

description:
Giving this 5 stars because it is pretty cool and unique

I hope the neighbors get driven insane as they are horrible people
author: Mike L.

description:
K and I stumbled upon this cash cow on an innocent evening walk, long ago.

CASH COW?

Step 1: Buy a stack of shrink-to-fit jeans at Mervyn's for cheap.

Step 2: Slide sans the cardboard. Repeat to noticeably wear in just the right places from your supafine behine.

Step 3: Sell these ass-tastic jeans to every chump around here dumb enough to spend more than $75 for a pair of fakey fade jeans. JEANS!

You'll be eating caviar and rolling like a star in no time.
author: Andy R.

description:
I am uber chicken. Even when it comes to playground slides. At least, these ones! I was a little shocked to see them at first...they look quite formidable. They're entirely concrete, and I had visions of eggshell skulls shattering on the ground dancing in my head....

And you want me to slide down these things on cardboard?! Okay, I guess. Might as well, being that a lot of research was done just to locate the slides.

Boy, was it fun. Soon we were giggling incessantly. Or at least, I was. Never got enough momentum to fly off the end, but I think it was because subconsciously I was afraid that suddenly the concrete would turn into metal.

Very "exsliding" (TM Grace Y.) indeed!
author: Ruth C.

description:
Wow, I can't belive it took me this long to get here!  Something about me not having a kid (borrowed one) might have something to do with it...

This place is so fun, it must have been built decades ago with much less regard to safety.  I went airborne every time I went down (except for the first time when I was chicken and wouldn't use the cardboard).  Two slides, side by side, so prepare to race. (The left side is slightly faster)  Wear grippy shoes so you can climb up to the top, it's steep and a bit slippery...like me.
author: Poppy C.

description:
Poor Grumpy S...and shame on you guys for Yelping about this over 100 times, there are things that are to be kept secret so a poor, quiet neighborhood doesn't get bombarded with drunken, obnoxious fun seekers at all hours of the night!
Is nothing sacred anymore?
author: Colleen B.

description:
A fun, hidden gem in the city. Contrary to rumors, it has NOT been torn down.

It is fun. It is fast. It is made of cement. I think the right slide goes slower than the left slide. When you're trekking to the top, there are steps on the far right. You can also walk up the steep incline slopes on either side of the slides. Depending on how you're sitting on the cardboard, you may be able to catch air on one of the dips. If you do, don't land on your tail bone because IT HURTS!

Steps to enjoy the slides:
1. Find the slides
2. Make sure there is no junk or glass on the slide that might hurt you or throw you off.
3. Bring up a piece of cardboard to the top
4. Sit on cardboard and slide down.
5. Repeat steps 3 & 4 until tired.
author: Christina C.

description:
I'm going to bring my 6 yr and 10 yr old nieces here and they will BEHOLD another reason why I'm their favorite uncle. 

Then I'm going to bring my twenty and thirty yr old friends here and have them BEHOLD the same thing. 

Tip:  Don't tell people you're going sliding. Just do it and surprise them, otherwise you'll get funny looks.
author: Teddy B.

description:
**6/27 Update**: Thank god, the poo is gone. Now I can resume going WHEEEEEEEE!

**5/20 UPDATE**: Uhh, okay, how can I put this eloquently... I took a hot date here yesterday, and to my utter dismay found the upper portion of the right slide smeared in feces. Good lord, this is a CHILDRENS playground. How can there be such sickos in this world?

**ORIGINAL REVIEW*
I've been going here since I was old enough to put band-aids on myself. Frankly I'm a little disappointed about the park maintenance: There used to be sweet child-painted murals on the sides of each slides, the play stuff at the bottom used to be more functional, and most importantly of all: each slide used to be painted with a different color. One was red and called "ketchup", the other yellow and "mustard". 

For the best ride possible:
-Wax paper UNDER cardboard. Wooh, supercharged!
-Try to use smaller pieces of cardboard. Extra flaps will grate on the sides and slow you down.
-Don't go on damp (foggy/recently rainy) days/nights; the moisture adds to friction and slows the ride
-The whole "sand makes things faster" idea is utter bullcrap., it only adds friction with slows you down, in addition to making the slide extremely dirty
