-Keep arms in, wear long sleeves, and pants, and closed shoes with decent treads-- the incline walking back up is steep, so flip-flops definitely will not suffice
-Use feet as brakes near the bottom. The sand pit is deceptively shallow.
-As hard as it is to not be loud, try to keep it down if you come here during the middle of the night, or the neighborhood residents will bitch you out Jerry Springer-style
author: T.Z. R.

description: This cute little park is a hidden gem in the city. The slides are great fun for kids as well as adults who don't mind screaming a bit in public. Use of cardboard for buttock protection is highly recommended.
author: C W.

description:
So, I have discovered a few things about this place. No cabbie in San Francisco has heard of it, it is not near enough to anything once you have had a cocktail or ten to walk, and it is not super easy to find after a cocktail or ten. 

Oh, but if you have the patience to ask all of the cabbies if they can get you there, if you have the patience to wander the streets of San Francisco with a big cardboard box under your arm, and the patience to stumble up and down a few hills............

WEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

These concrete slides rock!!!!
author: Drue C.

description:
Craziest. Slides. Ever. 

This place is awesome...totally hidden in a residential neighborhood so unless you go find it, chances are you won't be discovering it because you just so happened to pass by. 

Park in the residential neighborhood around it and walk on over. There usually isn't that many people there but plenty of cardboard for you to use. I've seen people bring their own wax paper to put underneath the cardboard, which supposedly makes you go faster. I'm not sure you want to do that because just sliding down on a piece of cardboard is already pretty darn fast. 

The slides look even more intimidating as you are sitting at the top, looking down, ready to slide because it's at that moment you realize how steep it really is. But the adrenaline rush is so amazing...you won't regret it. Remember to keep your arms in so you don't scrape your jacket against the concrete. 

What's even more fun? Go down simultaneously with a friend and race!
author: Connie W.

description: Use cardboard to go fast. Use wax paper to go National Lampoon fast. Weeee!
author: Geoff W.

description:
OK, now that the secret is out here's a reminder of the Slide Club rules:

1)  You don't talk about the Slides (Yelping is another thing...) 
2)  You don't talk about the Slides (Yelping is another thing...) 
3)  When someone says stop, or goes limp, even if he or she is just faking it, go home slide time is over!
4)  Only two sliders should race down Catchup and Mustard at a time. 
5)  One scream at a time.  Please be aware that people live by the slides and with the new popularity the increase in night noise could ruin the slide fun for everyone.  Have fun, but be cool people!
6)  Sliding with out shirts or shoes is not such a good idea.
7)  The slide races go on as long as they have to to determine the best slide and slider.
8)  If this is your first night at the slides you have to slide on the smallest and driest piece of slide-modified cardboard and you have to pinky-swear that you will do your best to follow all the Slide Club rules!

Now, get off your ass, away from your computer, go outside, and Slide On!
author: Christopher Y.

description:
I found these slides out on an urban hike thru the hood one day and just about fell over... WHAT a little hidden treasure. This is the kind of place that makes me so amazed I get to call SF home, because the entire city is liberally sprinkled with cool stuff like the Seward Street slides.

On a sad note, being the huge klutz that I am and given the fact that I was alone, I decided against a trip down. Hey, they're STEEP! Believe me, I know myself, and I most likely would have gone home with torn up knees and a chipped tooth. I'll wait til some drunken late night to partake, WITH company...

UPDATE 3/30/07 - Drue you're da best - that was SO FUN : ) drunken sliding rocks...
author: margot b.

description:
WARNING- only go down backwards if you have really good medical insurance! OUCH!!

from all of these reviews it seems that the slides are no longer one of san francisco's best kept secrets. 

alot of fun so bring your friends and get ready to act like a little kid once again.

WARNING- BE SURE TO INSPECT ThE SLIDE FOR OBSTRUCTIONS OR HAZARDS AS I HAVE SEEN SOME THINGS IN MY TIME HERE. YOU NEVER KNOW A TRIP TO THE SLIDES MAY RESULT IN A TRIP TO THE LAUNDROMAT OR WORSE, THE HOSPITAL. AND WE ALL KNOW THERE ARE SOME SICKO'S OUT THERE IN THIS WORLD SO LOOK OUT FOR BROKEN GLASS AS WELL.

so next time your in the area be sure to check out this local gem and you'll be wee wee weeing all the way home!
author: Scotty D.

description:
First I was afraid
I was petrified.
I told my friends there was no way
I'd go down that big slide.
But as I watched my friends catch air
And slide down those bad boys with such glee,
I took the plunge
It was so fun I screamed out "Wheeeeeeeee!"
And so you're back
From outer space

...wait what?
author: Krystle S.

description: A great hidden gem!  Congrats if you've found this.  This is a must do!
author: v v.

description:
I read all the enthusiastic reviews about these slides and finally decided to get a group of friends to ride our bikes there and check it out. They are quite a treat for us to have in the city, but they weren't as big as I thought they would be.  They are also not meant for people with wide asses because they are really thin. 

We went around 2 in the afternoon since it was not recommended to be there at night. Even though people tell you to bring large pieces of cardboard, the trick really is to bring long and thin pieces because anything too wide will cause too much friction and you won't get anywhere!  I went down the slides twice but after that, I pretty much got the jist of it and was like....okay, what now?
author: Jade L.

description:
Went last night for my first Seward Street Slide adventure, and IT. WAS. AWESOME. Best late night adventure that I've had in a LOOONG time. I'm still smiling and laughing thinking about it!

Definitely BYOC (bring your own cardboard) as the ones there were soaking wet or too small. And yes, there was a nasty pit of pond water at the bottom so be sure to avoid that when disembarking from said slide lest you get a soaking sneaker full of who-knows-what's-in-that-water.
author: D k.

description:
I went to a straight up porno house party in this neighborhood a few years ago. I thought there would be nothing in this world more hedonistically glorious than that house with an indoor pool/jacuzzi (where the living room was supposed to be, liquor flowing and undergarments dropping......)
until I stumbled out the street in my half nekkid drunkenness and flew down the Seward Street Slides.

One of those nights I'll tell my grand-kids about (sans the part about the drugs and loosing of ones panties)
author: Mary F.

description:
Sliding down concrete slides on dirty pieces of cardboard is pretty epic.

If you don't do well at climbing up steep and slippery slopes, use the stairs on the very far right. I didn't see these at first, so I subjected everyone to a bunch of unnecessary shrieks and omgimgonnadie's. Yes, going up was a lot scarier than going down. 

There are rules posted up that say adults cannot be there unless they have a child with them...which to me is BS! So if you're going to break the rules, make sure you don't disturb the neighboring houses. There's no need to come here drunk either because 1) That's just dangerous. And 2) You will have just as much fun while sober.
author: Lubs Y.

description: They are closed on Mondays. I have already submitted a change to Yelp. I will try to go on a different day to experience them.
author: Susie Q.

description:
I've been 2 additional times-- it is SO worth it to bring plastic trays!!!

Best use of concrete EVAR!
author: Julia R.

description:
A note to girly girls like myself:

Upon first sight of the Seward Street slides I had visions of blood and  my teeth being spit into the sand pit at the bottom. I reminded myself I had never broken a bone, and that is something I like about myself and didnt want to change. I said to myself, "These slides are a reminder of why you'd rather paint than jog. Of why as a child you took acting lessons instead of joining a sports team. Of why you subject yourself to Splenda rather than walk the 4 blocks to the #24 bus instead of taking the #21 until they intersect. YOU WERE AND ARE AN INDOOR KID." 

Then I had an even scarier thought than the dentures I was surely going to be fitted for after my first ride down.

What if I couldnt have a first ride down because MY ASS IS SO BIG it wont fit?

Years of images of my nicely rounded bottom flooded my head. I pictured the way I could lift up a cheek and let it drop a little. How I can feel it kind of bounce when I walk. I actually like my ass, but I didnt want it to hold me back in life. I already cant shop at Abercrombie or Bebe. What was next? Would I have to drink from a water fountain designated "ASS TOO LARGE TO FIT IN SLIDE ONLY"? I had to put a stop to this. 

We met again Saturday night. Softened cardboard pieces awaited me. I looked at the slide. It looked at me.

The slides are fun and all, but Im not gonna lie: Most of the adrenaline induced exhilaration while riding down was due to me feeling all the room on either sides.
author: Miss K.

description:
OK, so I had read about those, and they had been sitting in my Yelp bookmarks for a long while. Well, I finally made it there today.

Tips of the day:

1) The right slide (from the top) is a bit faster.
2) Forget cardboard. The real deal is to slide down those concrete babies on a cafeteria tray. (a sharing soul had left one there.): the right slide + plastic tray combo should be fast enough for you to catch some air in the last turn.
3) Once you've got the hang of it, it's time to wax it: another sharing soul had left a piece of soap at the top of the slide. Putting 2 and 2 together, we figured that soap would be a great way to wax that tray for extra speed. The result? I ended up going down fast enough to actually land @ss first in the sand, way beyond the end of the slide.

Do I hear good times?! Yes, I do.
author: Frederic B.

description:
Yes, they're hard to find.  Yes, you will likely suffer some manner of injury, the degree to which can largely be attributed to your level of adventure and your level of intoxication (not mutually exclusive.)  Yes, it's worth it.

We stopped at Latin American Club first to attain the appropriate level of "Slide Lubrication."  Told the bartender where we were going and asked her to make something to help us go down faster.  She made us Mudslides.
author: P J.

description:
The fun these slides provide is well worth the price of admission.  That price being all the skin off your elbows...  Aaaand possibly a bruised tailbone.  

  Some use cardboard, some use burlap or sleeping bags, wax paper was my vehicle of choice.  The wax paper is great because with each successive slide more and more wax builds up on the slide creating faster and faster runs.

  Bottom Line:  Such a great time!  Woulda been better without all those damn kids...(joking, joking)  Great way to spend Sunday funday!
author: Greydon U.

description: Great find! A neighbor showed us where these were, thanks! I felt like a bobsledder. You can either slide down with one of the cardboard pieces... or use a tray. Using a tray is much faster than using a cardboard piece. The right slide is faster/steeper than the left side. If you're planning to tray down this slide remember to jump at the end... or else you'll fall on your tailbone.
author: Laura F.

description:
Talk about secret smiles!  I took someone here as a romantic surprise once. When we finally found it, we slid down like four year olds at a birthday party.  Reminds me why I love San Francisco.  

Night time, you have to get your kicks quietly because the people living nearby don't exactly enjoy the whooping noises you tend to make when flying down a hill at 15 miles an hour on your butt.
author: Alicia D.

description:
SO much fun!  I felt like a little kid again!

These slides are perfect to go and lose yourself back into your childhood for a few minuets.  They are fast, fun and not scary at all.  When my friends and I were there small children were having a blast sliding down them.

Not exactly a "destination park", its really two slides, but worth going back if you're in the area or just looking to have some old skool fun.  This is def park that has local charm, something out of the ordinary and something the tourists don't get to see.  It's little things like this that make San Francisco so cool.
author: Jen K.

description:
Hike hike hike hike hike

Cardboard in place, booty on cardboard

Push off

HOLYSHITAKIMUSHROOMS!!

That was the most fun I've had in a while - with my clothes on!

The left slide is way more fast...I caught some serious booty air!
author: Christy L.

description:
Holy shit! I have pics of me and my cousins going down these slides as kids! Every time I'd ask the parents where they were taken they'd reply "Hmmm, can't quite remember that, sweetie." 

Acid must be bad for you, right.
author: petals o.

description:
I can't believe this.  I used to go here when I was a kid.  We used to call them the 'secret slides'.  One used to have a red stripe down the side, and the other had a yellow one.  My sis and I would have ketchup and mustard races.  And we would try going down backwards, and face first.  Those of you who have been there (which I'm shocked to find out that a great many of you have; they were, after all, a secret) know that there is a straight drop at the bottom.  Many a mouthful of sand have been had at Seward slides.

Once when we went `some kids had put sucked on now-or-laters all down the center of the slide.  We were bummed so my uncle Ted tried to wash em down the slide with a big bottle of Alhambra, but the slides stayed wet for hours.  A wet slide does not make for good sliding.

So, when you go, please don't leave sucked on now-or-laters.
author: Emily X.

description:
By far one of the funnest things to do in the city! The slide on the right gives you more air after the steep drop, so brace yourself! I recommend trying wax paper instead of cardboard, if you really want to get some speed! 

If you take your kids down the slide be sure to hold on to them when the slide drops off, it could be dangerous.
author: Christina D.

description:
A little shimmy to the edge, adjust the board, deep breath, a little push .....   SWOOOOOOOSH!!!, WHEEEEEEEE!, HOLY SHIT SHIT SHIT!, THUMP!!

Street slides only adds to my love SF even when I thought there was nothing more to love!  I HAD A GREAT TIME... SO FRIGGIN FUN!  It's probably the only playground where the # of adults there out numbered the # of kids.  Clearly only rule breakers and deviants go there because we all ignored the posted city penal code that states "No adults allowed unless accompanied by children".

Note: Right slide definitely has a bit more of a kick to it!

I happen to go with boys and we all know:
boys + possible danger = TROUBLE!

Oh so much trouble.  I'm thankful we all made it out of there alive with only a few bruises, twisted ankles and (who knew you could get them...) cement burns.  Add some sand and they might as well rename the place to Seward Street Slides of Death or Stupendously Suicidal Seward Street Slides.  Thank goodness for health insurance.  Happy sliding!
author: Christina C.

description:
Angry neighborhood residents be damned-this place is great. My suggestion: check it out during the day, and take your trash with you when you leave. And if you can't be bothered to schlepp your bottles and cans home with you, you can always dispose of them in Grumpy S.'s nice, big recycling can in the driveway adjacent to the park. Good lookin' out!

Seriously, though: the slides rock, and it would suck if this place were spoilt by a couple of unruly Yelpers. Respect the park and its neighbors (within reason, of course-once the eggs start flying, I say fight fire with fire), and we'll ensure that this remains a fun place for kids and adults alike.

And if anyone wants to go in on a dime bag and a lifetime supply of earplugs and/or sleeping pills for Grumpy S., let me know.
author: Shawn A.

description:
Very cool!!! The slides are built into the hillside in a residential area of San Francisco. I went there with my wife and three year old and we were the only ones there. On the way up the slides didn't look that steep but once you are halfway down you realize the slides are pretty steep. My three year old also loved it and was able to slide on his own. 

The cardboard left by other riders makes the slide ride significantly more fast. Wear long sleeves and pants unless you want road-burn on your legs and arms.
author: Josh P.

description: This place is AWESOME. Wear long pants and long sleeves to avoid concrete burn. Cool place to take friends who are visiting SF.
author: Kori M.

description:
A colleague texted this page to me during a recent trip to to SF, and a few of us found ourselves there shortly after midnight. First of all, the address provided here is purely approximate-- we were stumbling around for 30 minutes until -- honestly -- a deaf guy happened to walk past and helped us find the slides. If you follow the Yelp directions, know that you should not go up the tall concrete staircase at the end of the street. Instead, walk downhill just a bit until you reach the little street that goes a bit uphill. Walk up the hill for about 10 seconds and then hang a sharp left-- it will look like you're about to walk into a green hillside. The slides are tucked in there a bit.

The slides. First of all, there are exactly two slides, side-by-side. They are made of concrete and stretch at least 50 feet in length. The comment about finding a cardboard box to use as a sled is spot-on. We soon found a few and were racing down. Would have liked to know that the bottom lets you out about 3 feet over freakin' concrete before landing on me arse at 40 miles per hour.

Like someone else here said, the neighbors didn't appreciate our athletic prowess very much, and we left after about 10 minutes. I had to go back up for my jacket, and was grateful the rest of my friends had made it down the street and didn't see me fall in the slide as I tried walking down the hillside.

Definitely make sure you have a few in you before you hit the slides. Makes the entire experience take on a whole new level of whoa.
author: Sagar J.

description:
Probably the best thing ever.  It was in my neighborhood, and I didn't even know it!  Thanks Yelp!

Anyway, these slides are supreme.  They are like waterslides, but instead of tubes you ride cardboard and instead of water, you use sand... so I guess they are not so much like waterslides after all.

I am going to pass on the tips that I received from a 4 year old that sliding the same time I was:

1.  Pick a good piece of cardboard (supplied).  One you can hold on to and if it is made of slippery cardboard (painted) then it goes even faster.

2.  Use the steps, or risk sliding down the steep slide track.

3.  Bring up a buttload of sand with you.  Toss down slide, makes you go super super fast.

4.  Put feet on cardboard when you slide.  

5.  Race the person next to you.

Though I learned this from a 4 year old, I also learned that if you put the buttload of sand on the slide, then you slide and a 4 year old goes right after you, she will get sand in her eyes, cry and then her mom will make her go home - making the 25 year old feel really bad about playing on a slide.
author: Brittney B.

description:
Seward St. Slides & Ice Cream= Perfect Night whether you're hanging out with friends or on a date. Just make sure you're not making any noise if it's dark out (when the park technically closes)-otherwise you face the risk of a neighbor calling the cops on your ass like what happened to my friends and I. Luckily we got away with a warning, but not before facing the wrath of the neighbor and being lectured/ranted at.

Another word to the wise-don't, DON'T race down the second slide (the one closest to Douglass) on a McDonald's tray. I was racing a guy down and literally whizzed down the slide which sounds fun, but then I couldn't stop and fell on my ass sitting upright. I bruised my ass, still have a scar by my elbow from when my arm slammed against the concrete slide and had to walk bowlegged for almost a week. (At least I won the race and my friend has proof of it-I am all but a blur)
author: Jenny W.

description: I didn't know what to expect when I first headed to the Seward Street Slides. I was rather pleasantly surprised when I arrived! I thought I might have to bring my own cardboard box to slide down on before I came, but some kind soul had already left a few there. The slides are pretty small, but they get going faster than you think they would. You have to be very careful to go to the park at the correct hours though, because apparently there's some cranky old lady that lives next to the park and gets upset when people are having fun past 5 PM. In my opinion she should just move if it's so bothersome to live next to a damn slide.
author: Joseph F.

description:
Best slides in all of SF.  Been coming here since I was a little kid, about 35 years.  Now I bring my two boys who get to experience all the same joys and thrills.  
As others have mentioned, there is a small downside (no pun intended).  Over the past couple years we have had to endure the rantings of the next door neighbors.  Perhaps they really are suffering from lack of sleep and perhaps the irony is that it's been caused by late night revelers playing on the slides.  
But, really there is no excuse to yell or make remarks about young children using the slides in the middle of the day, during the open hours of the park.  The fact that they take video and pictures makes it all the more disturbing.
So to anyone who is hassled by these women, pay them no mind.  They are legitimately NUTS!  A couple years ago, while playing with the kids at the slides we could hear an argument coming from their house.  Their windows were wide open and one of them was berating a younger person (I know because she called him a "23 year old retard"!) at the top of her lungs.  My children (and others that day) were shocked to hear things like: You F'ing Retard...Get the F*cK out of here!"  The other person in the argument said a few things but he was barely audible.  She, on the other hand, loud enough to be heard a half block away.  It went on for about 45 minutes!   
I say this to the women of Seward Street...leave our kids alone and get some help!
author: Amilee K.

description:
How did they get there?  Where did they come from?  Why did they ever cancel Arrested Development?

The world will never know.
author: Chris R.

description:
I've been going to this place since high school and returned there today to find that it has suddenly exploded in popularity.  While my inner curmudgeon lamented this as the worst thing since Live 105 discovering the Pixies, it's probably a good thing that people are finding out about it, fun need not be hoarded.

I talked to the "witch of Seward slides" and found her to be quite reasonable, pointing out herself that the signs saying adults must be accompanied by children are complete bullshit.  Her only complaint was that people wake her up by screaming all night.  So go here, have fun on the slides.  If it's night time, be respectful and don't squeal like a pig as you go down.  Easy.
author: Mike H.

description:
Thanks to Yelp, my friends and I enjoyed a much needed adrenaline rush on a Sunday afternoon. Thank goodness no one else was around at the park (I feared mass interest in the slides after Jeremy S.'s ROTD) so we had the whole place to ourselves.

The slides aren't terribly difficult to find, just look for the red arches. We lucked out on parking but I assume this residential neighborhood usually is more difficult to park in.

If you forget your own cardboard, no worries, the park is usually littered with extra pieces, though no one can vouch for its cleanliness.

Upon first slide, it's kinda scary because you have no idea how fast you'll go or if you'll crack your head open on the concrete. But no worries, it's pretty darn safe and you can slow yourself down by bracing the sides.

As adults, unless you're into extreme sports or going to the carnival, we so rarely experience pure, simple elation...for FREE too. So throw caution to the wind and go for a couple of slides! (Just respect the neighbors and keep your voices down.)

Here's a tip: The left slide (if you are facing the slides, looking down) is a lot faster and you'll gain a little air going over the steep dip.
author: Viv C.

description:
They're worth checking out at least once, especially if you're in the neighborhood. My parents and I took my daughter and a friend and they had a blast - actually we all did.  We tried all combinations of cardboard, wax paper, and cardboard with wax paper underneath.  We each had our favorites.  I prefer the cardboard, my daughter and her friend both liked the wax paper, the combo was unnecessary overkill in our opinion.  We went after it had just rained and got quite muddy, but we went prepared to get dirty so it was fine.

Yelp's address says they're located on the corner of Douglass and Seward Street, but they're actually located in a garden b/t Corwin and Seward (the Corwin Street Community Gardens to be specific), near Kite Hill. We parked in the parking lot at the end of Corwin and walked down to the slides from there. 

More info about the "park": http://foundsf.org/index.php?title=Corwin_Community_Garden_and_Seward_Mini-Park
author: Jaclyn S.

description:
Yay!

Slides are a wonderful thing to have tucked away on a little side street between the Castro and Dolores park.

Bring some card board and speed down the short but steep concrete.  This isn't a play ground just a kick ass, speed demon slide.  I kept catching air over one of the humps on the way down... 

wheeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee!!!!!
author: Shayna N.

description:
So, after all the whoohaa about these slides I thought why not make an adventure out of my day and go to these slides. After getting directions that stated it would take a 10min walk to get to the park from the Castro station, it ended up to be a 2 hour journey to find this little nail in the wall park which only consisted of a bench and the two famous mountain cement slides. When finally finding then I must say maybe it was the day or even the time but the slides were covered with rain water, mud and sand. Just covered. This TINY park is also located in a area where its all families and homes so it is meant for the children who live in the close community and is not meant for random visitors so sneakiness is a Key factor. 

The slides looked awesome and I can see the appeal even under all the grime of water and mud but not worth going out of your way for.
author: Sarah S.

description: Fun, because I've never seen anything like it, but much smaller than I thought they'd be.  We didn't encounter the grumpy neighbors but did get some rug aka cement burns on my arms, and I'm small.  Not sure I'll make a habit of going here but glad I tried it once.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
I'd love to have one of these in my backyard, but I still can't get over the danger factor of going down a concrete slide...and perhaps, that's where a lot of the fun lies.  As much more exciting as it might seem, it's one place I wouldn't recommend coming to piss drunk.  I'm still reeling over a skinned finger and knuckle, so it's hard enough leaving injury-free when you're sober (or close enough to it).  

Otherwise, these slides are a great find!  Best of all, it's free, and accessible at any time of day, perfect for those random days/nights out.  It definitely takes you back to the carefree days of childhood.

I wish the slides were longer.  The fun ends much too quickly.
author: Marsha Z.

description: This place is awesome. Not only can you meet a bunch of random hipsters here, you see a bunch of people with their kids. It's really the essence of San Francisco manifested in a single friendly neighborhood park. I haven't been here since someone left the plastic lids, but last time I was there, we used cardboard and sand. Some people had a children's car with wheels that was a perfect size to turn this thing into a luge... Insane speeds were attained. Great peek-out-of-the-trees view of the rest of the Bay Area - this place is pretty high up in SF!
author: Andrew L.

description:
Years ago, I went sliding on a clear full moon night.  Now there are all types of ridiculous restrictions.  (Closed Mondays, No adults without kids, 10am-5pm only).  Be respectful to neighbors was the ONLY rule which made sense.

It must be the same people who move next to a busy street and then complain about the traffic.  You knew what it was when you moved there.
author: M C.

description:
1. must bring cardboard to sit.
2. watch the landing.
3. dont go at nite, respect thy neighbors.
be careful! my friend wore her heels down the slide, landed in the pit heel first, badly sprained her ankle.  8/
have fun!
author: Ethan L.

description: Wow these are fun, hard to find parking, but a blast. We went in the winter, it was dry and sunny, yet I think in the summer or on a warm, dry time of the year would be best because I could tell the slide was holding moisture that impeded our speed. Regardless, this is a secret little happy spot to have some fun. I found these on yelp so I'm stoked to pass on a great review.
author: Craig G.

description:
I found this place on Yelp last week, and went THAT DAY with my boyfriend, after work. All the reviews are true, except that I found it quite easy NOT to hurt myself - however, I can definitely see that after a few drinks it would be a bit more challenging. 

We had SO much fun! We were shooting down the slides, and running back up immediately, laughing the whole way. It really was like being in elementary school again. I highly recommend you give it a go, drunk or not.

There were a few fast food trays laying around from past visitors, so my bf grabbed one, slid forth - and flew! He caught a little air on the drop, and even more air at the very bottom. A definite cherry on top, but be careful or you'll end up on your ass!

PLUS - I was super proud that I found a local gem that he had NEVER heard of in his 15 years in San Francisco!!! 

WeeeeEeeeeee!
author: Alexa S.

description:
Since my boo was getting all excited over wanting to come check this place out, we ventured on over there.  The journey was great, but not this particular destination.  The slides aren't even that exhilarating and long to go down on.  Yes it is random and it's fun to race on, but it was also pretty dirty and what not (maybe we should've gone on a sunnier day?).  Thanks to whoever left the trays there, but maybe I'd also BYOT.  

I dig the idea and concept, just not the actuality and reality of it all.  There does need to be more random places for fun times and natural highs, though.  But, the best place so far would be the Sand Dune Park in Manhattan Beach.  It's good, clean, great for a workout, and I wouldn't get sick of going there multiple times.

Basically, it can do better.  But you might as well check this out once in your life.  Life's too short to not try new things, right?  You never know when you'll live it up with something (or someone).
author: Lili K.

description:
I know a couple of awesome gals that live on top of these beautiful couple of slides. They had a party. So many people. So many beers. 

We decided to go down the slides after most guests went home. One friend who was way too wasted tried her "go down the thing while nobody else looked, probably face down" move, and lost her two front teeth. 

Seward Street Slides - 1
Our Poor Friend - 0

Don't drink and slide.
author: Mac O.

description:
"Wheeeeeeeeeeee!  Ahhhhhhhhhhh!  Oh my god, make it stop!"

Like a roller coaster without seat belts is the best way to describe the slides!  After a nice sushi dinner, my friends decided to take me to the Seward Street Slides.  

"Hey, Celeste, have you been to the Seward Street Sides?" -- Linda
"The what?" -- Celeste
"Let's go there?" -- Linda
"Now?" -- Ronnie
"Yeah!" -- Linda
"What?  Where are we going?" -- Celeste
"Just don't worry about it." -- Linda
*Ronnie makes U-turn and we head towards Castro from Inner Richmond...

We finally arrived.  Ronnie opens the trunk of his car and takes a newly folded cardboard box out.  Right then, I knew exactly what we were going to do.  

The slides did not look scary at all.  I might have been a bit nervous, but I wasn't scared.  As I made my way up to the top, I felt butterflies in my stomach.  I put the cardboard box down, then I sat on it with my bottom and feet on it.  I literary felt like I was going to fly off after the bump.  There was no way of stopping it.  It didn't help that I had nice pants on and flip-flops.  Before I can even think of a way to try and stop, it was too late... I feel off the slide on my bottom.  Hurts... it still hurts a bit now, but definitely a wonderful, fun experience.  

Awesome, Amazing and Astounding... good times!  Thanks Ronnie and Linda :-)!

Use slide with CAUTION!  Not for children and not for drunks!
author: Celeste M.

description:
Yelpers!  Thank you for introducing me to these slides...

HELLA FUN + FREE = NO BRAINER

I brought my 11 year old niece to the slides so I could have an excuse to ride them myself.  When we got there, we were the only ones, so we had the slides all to ourselves for about 30 minutes.  The first round, the speed and air you catch scared the bejeezus out of my niece, but after my mom pointed out the sign that said "No adults unless accompanied by children", my niece let loose and really started having fun.  Now, whenever she comes up to visit, the first thing she wants to do is come back to the slides.  

As for me, it's been a long time since I felt so exhilarated or laughed so hard at such a simple pleasure, made me feel like a kid again.  We ran back up the stairs over and over like 20 times!  Fortunately, no loss of skin, or major bruises for any of us on this visit.

Bonus:  Eventually, others started showing up, one lady rode down the slide so fast that she flew out of the bottom end and landed straight on her @$$!  She was kinda embarrassed, but it was quite comical to watch....heh heh heh.
author: Burrito M.

description:
20 minutes 
1 skinned wrist and back
3 slides sitting on damp cardboard
Me doubled over about to wet my pants I'm laughing so hard.

Seriously... Sammy S...you are coming with us next time we are bored/hungover on a Sunday afternoon!
author: Nancy B.

description:
wax paper n' cardboard. Warn the newbie on their first run to WATCH OUT. Long sleeves. Don't scream too loud.
SOooooo much fun.....
author: y-von-e l.

description: One of my favorite things to do in the city.  I always bring visitors here:) They are reallyyyyy fast!
author: Torrey R.

description:
Want some good, cheap fun?  No, not a hooker......

Who knew?  slides in the middle of the city..... So I had to go and see for myself.

Everyone has already written all the rules.

Now go and try it yourself!   just keep your arms in.......make you feel like a little kid all over again ;-)
author: MiYong E.

description: My bf dragged me to this place and I was like, "are you sure?", especially after I saw how steep this thing was.  We brought some boxes to sit on before we went down the slides.    It was fun!  Most importantly, because the slides are well constructed, it was really safe.
author: Ka P.

description:
Back when I was your age,  I lived in the South Bay.  My girlfriend was spending a summer in SF, and it was our chance to "explore the city" and "take advantage of what it has to offer" and "not be completely lame".  

So we went here? 

Yeah, we fail.  Got here.  Looked at the slides.  Looked at the puddles on assorted parts of them.  Turned around.  Went to read books in Dolores Park.  We unfail.
author: Jack S.

description:
Dirty cardboard and annoying neighbors makes this one of my new favorite spots in the city. And an awesome place to get a fun work out.

I think I went down the slide about 20 times in 40min. Ever time was more fun then the next. It's a good work out running up the side of the slide. Thank goodness for the chains next to the slide to hang onto. If not for them I would have fallen a lot more then I did.

I haven't felt that young in years!
author: Cat R.

description:
*edited Sunday, Aug 26th*
If anyone reads reviews PRIOR to attending places, take careful note:
STAND UP WHEN YOU REACH THE BOTTOM OF THE SLIDE!
this advice my friends might save you a whole lot of pain and possibly a trip to the doctor.
so, the story is quite plain. cindy and I went with two people who calle themselves Pete and Rhett.
Pete had been to the slides before, yet still insisted Cindy and I slide first (mind you its dark). We are great people, so we accept this invitation and without further ado grab cardboard and even let Pete and Rhett push us. 
As we fly at the speed of 1,000000000mph down the cement the slide ends and i keep flying, until gravity takes over and i at the speed of 1,0000000000 fall flat on my ass.

my tail bone hates me.

the slides are fun. i can honestly advise that they are safer in the day light.

go go go!

I'M COMING!!!!!! 
update on the actual visit later, but i was so excited that i couldn't wait till Friday!
author: Helen N.

description: Post halloween party and needed something to motivate us out of the bed ... so we came here around 4:50pm. We were actually afraid we would be late from sitting in the SF traffic!! So the 4 adults brought carboard boxes and went down the slides. I was the first to go and with my bubble wrapped box, I slid down the fastest, practically flying off the end and landing in the hard sand. BE CAREFUL Guys!!! But I ran back up and went again anyways!! The mom that was with her kids, gave us some wax paper they used and that also made it very exciting.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: I don't even understand why the tattle tale lady doesn't just move. Or get some earmuffs or something. The last time I was there, I was with my best friend, boyfriend, and sister. We were having the time of our lives! It was 12 noon, we were the only ones there, and we were just laughing at my sister because she ate sand as she came down the slide. This lady, though... MY GOD. HAS SHE NEVER HAD A GOOD TIME IN HER LIFE?! She walked out from her house and was like SHUT UP BLAH BLAH BLAH. We just kept laughing and sliding until my sister's pants ripped.
author: Charlotte D.

description:
These sides showcase the wonders of concrete.  Imagine all of that rebar and stirups.  Gets me hot just thinking about it.  

After you get over the fact that you are staring at an engineering marvel, perhaps one of the 7 wonders of the man made world, and actually slide down you realize that engineering can be fun!

So get some cardboard and head out to the wonder that is the concrete slides.  Just a warning, if the cardboard comes to a dead stop halfway down the slide you WILL be flung head first down the remaining portion......but even when you scrape and bruise yourself you will have a hell of a time.
author: flip it up u.

description:
My cousin and I got so lost finding these slides. We dutifully toted our cardboard around San Francisco for about 45 minutes before we gave up, stashed it in someone's recycling bin, and decided to head elsewhere. We turned around, walked for a while and suddenly...oh, THERE THEY ARE! Too bad our cardboard was long gone. Fortunately, a kindly man who was replacing the bags in the trash cans gave us a bag, which worked out ok. I think it may have slowed us down a bit, but it was still amazingly fun. 

Next time I'm bringing waxed paper!
author: Maeve C.

description:
I grew up next to a gigantic cement slide which left many fond memories in my heart (not to mention a number of scars on my knees and elbows).  Cement slides are about as close to sadomasochism as I get.  And this one is my new favorite San Francisco pastime... 

throw some sand on the slide, and/or use some waxed cardboard to really get going (bring your own cardboard... the leftovers there are nasty looking).  Keep your arms in to avoid a trip to the thrift store for some stylish elbow patches for your jacket.
author: Sarah J.

description:
Oh how I hate you slides of terror. And yet, how I love thee!

First off, don't use new pieces of cardboard. "Genius idea Cat!" AH!

I was frightened. But the women next door was more frightened. Or more of a whore. I don't know.

It was seriously 6:00PM, and she was opening her window and yelling at us. "Uhm...it's late. Could you go home. People live here!"

Woman, it's 6PM! Just because it's dark doesn't mean it's late. But trusty Cat with her Cat mouth. She was all "Meow meow meow" and told her off. Hehe!

But the slide hurt my ass, and scuffed my jeans.

If you're going, enjoy yourself. But bring your own cardboard, and wear jeans you don't mind scuffing. WOOT!
author: Nicolas H.

description:
One of the funnest (yes, funnest!) things you can do for free. 

Especially a blast after a night of heavy drinking. Make sure to bring some wax paper so you can really fly!

*Note -- don't do this bare skinned!!
author: David G.

description: These slides are awesome, and an historical San Francisco tradition, but there's been some problems lately. 1/1/10am: someone has poured some kind of sticky liquid (honey water or something) that makes the slide unusable (this is not the first time). It looks like it will come off with the rain, but it's a bummer. Please report this kind of behavior to the police!  Also, please abide by all posted rules at the park to keep it fun and safe for all!
author: Jon V.

description: Neck injury notwithstanding... I braved the more whee-worthy Seward Street Slide with carefree abandon...  Please see photos.  Wheeeeeeeee, indeed, my inner child.  Wheeeeeeeee.
author: Marjorie B.

description:
After figuring out just how slippery and how steep a concrete hill really can be, you'll get to the top of these slides and wonder how you ever thought they were so small. You'll sit down on a piece of cardboard and start to doubt that you'll ever start going downhill at all (use sand).

You'll slide halfway down, and just before the big drop-off, you'll spend the last half-instant you have thinking,  "WTF DID I JUST GET MYSELF INTO?!!"

And at the bottom, when the smell of burning cardboard dies down, you'll wonder just how many times you'll go down before getting sick of it (read: never).


The slide on the left (view from the top) is DEFINITELY faster.
author: Kyle S.

description:
Are you a little down and need a quick pick-me-up? Find the Seward Slides and instantly turn into an 8-year old all over again. Before you make the hike up to the top, grab a piece of cardboard from the sandpit. It will make your ride that much faster.

This would be a perfect place to break the ice on a first date.

No need to bring kids with you. Adults riding the slides get more fun out of the slides then the little tikes do. Especially in the wee hours of the morning, after certain adult, drinking establishments close. I feel sorry for the people who live in the neighborhood. Do they ever get used to all the grown ups screaming and laughing?

Next time, I want to replace the cardboard with a plastic fast food tray. Hey, I'm an adult AND I have insurance so why not?

Still not convinced? Check out all of the hilarious videos of the slides on YouTube ( look under Seward Slides).
author: Kathleen N.

description:
Be careful of your tailbone and knees.  If you let your knees brush up against the concrete as you go down, you might get a hole in your pants.  Tailbone injuries can happen if you go through the slide too fast and can't slow down at the end.

As you go around the curve, you will get a little air between your tush and the slide.  It's a little scary, but the element of risk adds to the fun.  

This is a fun thing to do with friends after a house party.
author: Rachel E.

description:
Located in a very residential area, so please try not to scream so loud.. although it may be hard sometimes.  We had so much fun sliding down with paper trays and wax paper.  Someone was nice enough to lend us some wax paper, it was awesome!    

Tips:
1. walk up the stairs on the left, not next to the slide because it can get very slippery.
2. If you look from the bottom, the left slide is more "crazy".  You may get lift up on the air in the last segment and come down again.
3. Don't wear glasses, especially those bug eye sunglasses.. They'll fall off and you'll look so ridiculous.
4. The sand puddle at the end really stinks.  It's mixed with decomposing paper trays, and who knows... homeless pee?

But what the hell..  the fun is so overwhelming that it's worth doing this shit over and over again.  I love it!
author: Carina N.

description:
This is a lot of fun, and in a nice part of town, but I have to agree with the yelpers who think its over hyped on this site.  I was expecting this MASSIVE slide that scaled the side of a San Francisco mini mountain, no such luck.  Its about as long as a standard park slide, but to its credit is real fast.  The ride lasts about 1.5 seconds.  When you're at the bottom, you get the whiff of burnt cardboard, which immediately worries you that your ass is on fire.  After about ten minutes, the thrill is gone.  I was with my gal's little niece, so we were there a lot longer than we would have been if she wasn't.  As for slides, its not nearly as good as the big yellow one at a carnival, or a water slide at any water park, or the water slide at your friends in ground pool.  It is better than any slide at McDonald's funland though.    If you're really stupid into slides, then check the one at Bernal Heights Hill (below the hill to the south, towards Mission St.).  It is a standard OG schoolyard slide, straight and metal.  Wrap your hoodie around your booty and you fly down at mach 8, maybe 9, then get ejected into wood chips.  DO IT!

Oh, not sure why people would want this to be a secret, it was 6 o'clock on a Saturday and no one was there when we went.  I hate sharing too, but c'mon, its in a public park for a reason.  The best time to go would probably be after the bars with a loud ruckus group of friends.  The neighbors are friendly.
author: Adam M.

description:
"Those are the slides?"...I was not impressed when I first caught glance of the Seward Street Slides.  They didn't really look like much -- not especially high nor long nor steep -- so I thought I could take them on with no problem.
I grabbed my piece of cardboard, climbed up the lil hill/steps (okay, that wasn't exactly easy) and proceeded to scoot my booty onto the "so not impressive" slide....and "WHOOAA...OOOHH SH*T! "...that slide was damn fast!!!  
I love these slides and you even get some air with the little bump in the middle.

Okay...so, I was wrong. These slides were awesome!  Now I know....it's not the slide, it's the ride....got it!
author: Joanne S.

description:
Totally worth the ass pain.

The mcdonald's tray idea is great though. I have to try that.
author: Olivia W.

description:
It's like one of the cities best kept secrets. I remember thinking to myself after reading about this place on Yelp that I would have to try this and see what all the hype is all about. And after 4 drinks at badlands I decided along with my friend, why not?

Let me tell you that this is an experience you are better off driving to for the experience. We hiked up steep ass hills just to get there and when we made it we had to climb to the top...but all that effort paid off when we took our first trip down the slide...running back up to the top to experience the slide again and again and again...our 5th time was our final and the most fun.  I wish the rest of the people I care for were able to experience this with me, but there will be other times...I intend on coming back and I won't be back alone.

5 Big Red Ones.
author: James J.

description:
OMG! So fun! 

I came here with two people. One person was not into it, the other was totally into it. Please go with someone that is into it. It was seriously one of the best times I've ever had on slides before. 

If facing the entrance to both of the slides, try the left one. I found it to be extra fun. At one point it drops too steeply and you catch air. Granted gravity and your arse do not agree with concrete so much but it was TOTALLY worth it.
author: Alex M.

description: After all these years, all it takes for a thrill is an S-curve concrete luge and a piece of lifted cardboard. Sure beats a hot spark plug and a rock, I suppose. But after dark, both are illegal. (Is there something wrong with the system here?) Wear your soft-soled shoes, the neighbors are tattletales.
author: Ligaya T.

description:
"When I get to the bottom I go back to the top of the slide
Where I stop and I turn and I go for a ride
Till I get to the bottom and I see you again
Yeah yeah yeah "

I can't believe I actually slid down these things. In a dress. Without injuring myself.

And that my ass wasn't too wide to fit.

Awesome!
author: Vanessa R.

description:
Holy Crap, this place was a hoot! And what a score! Thanks again Yelp!!

Nestled between two homes in a very residential area with small winding roads, Seward Street Slides is one of San Francisco's best kept secrets. Clearly it's not a secret here, but I can assure you, it's pretty "under the radar" if you will.

And by the way, , , , these slides are a little scary. Not sure how a kid would do on them. I'm somewhat of a thrill seeker and I LOVE roller coasters, white water rafting, etc. I found these slides to be a little intimidating. I dunno if it's because of the concrete or I'm just not aging well. But I felt like a bit of a puss. O-well. I'll get over it. And I'll be back!!
author: alexa c.

description:
Be a kid again. Sure to make you very happy.
It's hidden in a little neighborhood, so you feel like you found a secret place. Climb up the side by holding a chain, bring a camera, wait your turn...  my friend swears the right side (going down) is faster, as do the little kids who frequent the place.

Everyone is willing to share cardboard (yes it's faster than straight pants).
You will go away feeling warm and happy.
author: Mindy L.

description:
Yes, this place is sweet.

I kinda feel bad for the people who live on either side of the slide...I bet they're sick of hearing that "SSSHHHHUUSH" all the time...

Hard to find parking...but worth the trip.
author: Mike S.

description: A great San Francisco attraction for free. A concrete slide. Great for Kids. Bring your own cardboard to sit on. The fast on is on the left. Don't be discouraged if you can't find the place, listen for kids screaming on the decent.
author: Michael A.

description:
"All adults must be accompanied by children." -Sign 

It's not that easy to find, I suggest snooping around.  Careful not to disturb the neighbors.   

The first time going down was a little awkward.  I was almost embarrassed I enjoyed it that much.  I giggled like a school girl.

Highly recommended.
author: Jay B.

description:
OMG!  Could this place be any more great?  I went with a few friends on a beautiful Wed. afternoon and there was no one there, it so nice and quiet up there, and the little park was so relaxing (after we hurled ourselves down a hill of course).  

There is a great sign at the top too:  "No adults allowed unless accompanied by children"
author: Steven Q.

description:
It's a fun place to let your inner child out, but if you're a dull pencil, don't bother coming.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
I have been completely charmed by these slides since I first saw them- they're whimsical and super-cool and bring out my inner child. 

There's a trick to them! Without a braking procedure you start going awfully fast. If, like me, you're not nimble enough to land running, then you have to press your legs against the sides of the slide to slow yourself down before you go flying off the end. (This means you have to firmly spread your legs open. Some of us are better at this than others.) 

My only complaint is that I wish the city would put some of that recycled rubber kiddy playground squishy flooring on the ground under the slides. This would result in fewer injuries to the coccyges of the drunk.
author: Nicole J.

description:
Oh, great fun!
http://flickr.com/photos/kowitz/1681640734/
author: Braden K.

description:
All I have to say is: keep your arms tucked in. Don't panic and try and brake using the inside of your arms. Unless you like losing skin.

Or maybe just go when you're sober.
author: Blake D.

description: Fun little gem in the city. Went with family and two 4 year old little girls. Not sure who had more fun!  There was cardboard left there for us to use and there are hours posted but early afternoon on a Thursday it was all ours.
author: C B.

description:
Great place to take non-natives and natives alike. Good scary fun, great at night to have a beer or 2 and see if you can avoid injury. It's at the top of a calf burner of a hill, so you might want to drive. And yeah-- watch that tailbone. These slides aren't made of marshmallows, and that's not cotton candy you land on at the end...
The fun lasts for just long enough, then you're over it and it's time to check out the view over SF a block or 2 away on the bench that gives you one of the best views in the city. I wish I knew what that was called... I'll yelp it.
author: Brandy E.

description: Totally Amazing!!! We played on these for a while. Cardboard with wax makes it faster and watch your elbows and other body parts for cement burn if you hit the side going down. Ride it waterslide style, legs and arms crossed! Now as for the psycho lady- the legend is real. She came out at 4p. yelling about needing her quiet time and when we just stared she went into personal insults. She is friggin NUTS!!!! SO I encourage everyone to go to the slides, bring all your friends and have a nice loud time at this PUBLIC PARK!!!!! Maybe bring some lithium to the throw at Mrs. Psycho.
author: Taylor S.

description:
Bring that cardboard; oh, bring that cardboard! 

I must say that I had my doubts about the slides; I need a high "fun" quotient and not just a "nostagia" quotient (which I was expecting was the appeal).  But the fun is real; I am a believer in the Seward Street Slides. 

Not to say that this is something to do every weekend, but every once in a while this will be totally cool to rock with some friends.  Yeah, you and a friend will be good-to-go at the same *exact* time; the slide is actually two in tandem.  Coordinate with a "1", "2", "3", "GOOoooo".. "Ahhhhh!".  Hmmm.. I guess you could get a posse going down at the same time if you'd like to "train" yourselves, one in each slide groove; grab those hips or shoulders in front of you! 

In any case, I guarantee a scream, an "oohhh" - or dare I say: a yelp - your first time down the polished concrete of the slides; the middle drop is steep.  I'm inclined to say it's "two-stories" high, but they that sounds like you're dropping out of a building.  Yeah, so it's not that high, but it does have a nice double drop (i.e. slides, then flattens out *slightly*, then drops again); it's taller than your average playground slides for sure.  And set solidly into the earth. 

There is a little bit of a climb to get to these guys, but they aren't as high up on Twin Peaks as I had thought.  I'd say maybe a 10 min walk from Castro and 18th (or maybe a few minutes more if you haven't been on the stairclimber in awhile). 

In short, the Seward Street Slides probably won't change you life (unless you go down them naked), but *are* a 4-star attraction; another little gem in a city full of them.  And don't forget the cardboard!  If you do, there is a supermarket as well as a few corner stores on 18th on the way to the slides (towards Castro) that could probably hook you up.
author: Eric H.

description:
I wish they'd build some of these near my house. I'd go all the time. Cheap SF fun. There was cardboard available.

Make sure you keep the noise down, and the neighbors are pretty nice about reminding you.
author: Jen T.

description: There are now locked gates barring use to the slides.... see, a few drunk a#holes ruined it for the whole city!!!
author: reg b.

description: The citation was one hundred and seventy dollars for disobeying a park sign.  Now I'm broke.  There go my happy memories of this place, doubt I will be back.
author: Zack S.

description:
WOW!

So, introduced to these slides during a neighborhood tour.  What great fun!  Just grabbed a piece of cardboard off the ground...........I know.......was that REALLY a good idea?............ran up the stairs, threw down the cardboard and jumped in.  Wholly crap!  Beware as this slide (on cardboard) is quite inconspicuously fast and I even caught a little air.  The landing was a bit less than eloquent, as there is a pit that catches your feet first and your butt second.  Great fun and quite the thrill.  

BEWARE THOUGH.........................be sure to wear a long sleeve shirt before the ride as I got a raspberry scrape under my arm...........its still healing, a week later.  I guess I'm a sick minded human!
author: Grant T.

description:
This is an awesome detour on a Saturday night!  It made feel like a kid again and totally invigorated me.  It's places like this that make this city great.

When I went there were already cardboard boxes laying around so there's probably no need to bring your own.  But next time, I'll follow T.T.'s advice and bring wax paper!
author: Mahogany G.

description:
Wheels are a great invention.

As are band-aids.

And ibuprofen. 

Lots and lots of ibuprofen.

So much ibuprofen.
author: Mat K.

description:
Now you can feel like a kid again and it's free!

The Seward Slide Park is awesome. My friends and I checked it out on a sunny weekday and had the entire park to ourselves.  

Here are a few suggestions:

1. Wear sensible attire - athletic shoes, jeans that you can get dirty and I'd also suggest long sleeves just in case your arms rub up against the slide (my brother got a pretty bad friction burn).

2. Bring cardboard.

3. For added speed, sprinkle a little sand on the slide.

4. Don't go at night since it's smack dab in a quiet neighborhood with houses built up right next to the park.
author: Keau K.

description:
Appropriate hype on this one. 

Make sure you take a handful of sand up with you, place it under your cardboard to reduce the friction and speed up your ride. Done correctly it can get pretty intense.
author: Bryan E.

description:
FUN! But I was only brave enough to go down once.

There were a few McDonald's trays lying around- and boy, do those give you a lot of speed. I used the cardboard method and I don't think it went as fast as the plastic trays. I luckily didnt get any scrapes or land too hard on the sand. I think people were saying that the right slide is a little faster than the left one. If you dont go down with the cardboard, its not very fast at all- some lady was sliding down with her dog down and the dog seemed to enjoy it as well!

I also went during the afternoon, so I didn't get scolded by any neighbors as some other Yelpers have mentioned.
author: Retired B.

description:
This place is great. I love san francisco...I've been here 12 years and I keep finding new things. 

Make sure to wear cheap jeans. You may wear out your new ones.
author: sam p.

description:
Taking your kids here?  Probably not such a good idea...

Wanna feel like a kid again? GO. NOW. 

and bring a piece of cardboard.  

screw amusement parks.

Now that's how slides worked when I was a kid.
author: Gabrielle J.

description:
a couple of drinks at bars = $40 dollars
cardboard = $0 dollars
sliding down like a little kid at 2am buzzed = PRICELESS

OMG it took a while for my friends and i to find the Seward Street slides especially since none of us never been there. However, after running around the neighborhood in the middle of night, we finally struck gold. The Seward Street slides are SOOOO cool. We tried not to make too much noise for the nearby neighbors but you cant help but yelled "WEEEEEE" as you go down the slide. Definitely made my Saturday night a night to remember. :)

SF is loveee.....
author: Carol Y.

description:
I was up in SF a few weeks ago and after non-stop Bhangra dancing at the Yerba Buena Arts Center and a bonfire gathering at Ocean Beach we decided there was no better way to end the evening/start the morning (it was about 1:30 AM) than to check out the Seward Street Slides! 

When we first arrived I was tired and really not all that interested in these concrete slides of doom which is what they were made out to be.  However once we climbed our way to the top of the slides, with a slight fear of cracking our heads on the way down, Jenny and I saddled up together on one slide, almost Cool Runnings Bobsled Style (although they were actually too narrow for me to sit behind her with my legs by her sides, so i just went right after her) and we went down.  WHOOSH! WHOOSH!  Two awesome dips later we were at the bottom of the slide and already trying to scramble our way up again!  Brief yet exhilarating!  We went down 3 times in a row.  AMAZING!

I highly suggest checking out this neighborhood gem.  However, we recently found out that apparently you're not supposed to go on the slides after sunset/before sunrise, which is probably a good idea anyways, otherwise the residents will probably get very very pissed, as one dear friend of mine recently found out, and they will call the cops.  So be courteous but have fun too!
author: Emily S.

description:
Free.  Exhilarating.  Cute... and simple, honest, wonderful fun.

I was a kid again.... for.... 15... minutes.

thanks slides!  thanks!

YELPERS!!! :::  be respectful, and be quiet.  It is a neighborhood!  If you aren't expect to be yelled at... at length... by some woman to the southwest on the hill.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
I have a love/hate relationship with this place....

I give it 5 stars based on it's sheer coolness.
but...i also give it 1 star based on the fact that I will have scars for life because of..well...my drunken behavior, but that's beside the point. 

My only advise: Use the cardboard to your ADVANTAGE...and don't let IT use YOU!
author: Cindy H.

description:
Pick the right side if you want to go faster. 

Tuck your arms in OR bring band-aids.

Bring some hand sanitizer.

I thought it was pretty cool how there were more adults than kids. I want to go back and ride down with an ice cream cone.
author: C. Z.

description: Great way to kill a few hours on a nice Sunday afternoon. It sort of reminds me of something straight out of the Adventures of Pete and Pete: this super secret holy grail of playground equipment, surrounded by Adults who you have to be quiet around or you'll anger them (too bad Artie didn't show up). We stayed there for about 30 minutes and at least half a dozen other groups came by during that time. Plentiful cardboard scraps too, or be brave and bring waxpaper.
author: Adam D.

description:
It's true! Beware the angry old lady that lives next door.

I went with a friend at 9PM on a weekday night, and I had barely made it down when this grimacing shrew approached me and said "What do you think you are doing! Didn't you read the SIGN!!!".

And I just mumbled an apology and pretended to walk away... Then my partner in crime came sliding down and we erupted in laughter and fled the scene before she could call the cops.

I mean seriously, what a miserable existence she has. She CHOSE to live next to the slides. And yeah noise sucks at 3AM but it was only 9PM!

What a joyless waste of life.
author: Trey F.

description: The most exciting free adventure in San Francisco, hands down. Though when I went air-born at the bump in the slides, I nearly pissed my pants!  Two out of the three of us left with burn marks inside our biceps from trying to slow ourselves down, so I highly recommend wearing long-sleeves.  If you live in San Francisco, you need to do this at least once.
author: Melaina E.

description:
So your work day sucked. Your boss was a jerk, the project's over budget, and you wish you were a kid again.....COME HERE and you will be 8 y/o all over again - no bills, no worries, no deadlines. 

This a FREE time machine - where you can let loose, hit the slides over and over, have gut splitting laughs, and know that all will be A-OK.
author: Button W.

description:
I originally posted this in 07, but it needs refreshing.  The woman next door might be the most vocal, but all of us in the neighborhood are suffering from the extreme rudeness of nighttime sliders.  It is regularly 2 or 3 groups a night now.  It was never this way before the Yelp reviews- so I'm talking to you.  Don't come at night.   Just don't.  Don't leave your trash- and yes- that cardboard that you think someone else will use is trash.  Don't park illegally- the street is narrow enough.   It's just basic politeness, folks.  The park is meant to be enjoyed.  But even during the day, if your inner child is not accompanied by your inner mother, you should stay away.  

7-24-07
Hey Yelpers... Thanks to your enthusastic response to this post, we in the neighborhood have lost all patience with the night time noise problems in the park.  Look at it. It is surrounded by residences.  When you yelp, or holler, or whoop your way down our dear once-semi-secret slides at 11, or 2, or 4 in the morning,  about 30 people wake up and think evil, evil thoughts about you.  And now, sorry, but we're going to call the cops a lot more often.  Like, all the time.  Because the park is closed at night.  And it's a place for kids, so it shouldn't smell like beer.  And we shouldn't have to pick broken glass out of the sand. And did I mention the noise?
author: Grumpy S.

description:
3.5 stars for being 2nd best giant cement slides in SF.

I was surprised that no one mentioned the giant set of slides in the children's playground (w/ carousel) near Kezar.
author: david w.

description: Yay for free fun.  Grabbed some free cardboard at the bottom and bombed down the slides.  Burned some calories walking up the hill to get there.  Seems like a win to me.
author: Marie B.

description: We were so excited to take family to try out these slides on New Year's Eve...when we got there we found someone had poured a heavy syrup down the slides to prevent them from being used. It is sad that there are people out there that prevent and rob fun from children and their families during the holiday season. I feel sorry for their poor unhappy souls. Bah humbug to those people!!
author: angela h.

description:
Oh. So. Great!  And my friends even have convenient children I can borrow so I don't break the rules! ("No adults allowed unless accompanied by children.")

This is one of my favorite "secret" things to do (and proudly show off when friends come to visit) in San Francisco.  Some of the others are the Presidio Pet Cemetery and the mystery spot in Golden Gate Park where it looks like the water runs uphill.  Does anyone need further proof that San Francisco is the best city in the US?
author: Jude F.

description:
I kind of thought they were going to be longer...

but still, there is some fine slidin' to be had here. And the search for this place made for an epic Saturday adventure. [Your search probably won't be nearly as long if you realize that 'Seward St Slides' means that the slides are on Seward St. My friends and I have no collective map sense.]
author: Annee T.

description:
For beginners, I recommend starting off using cardboard. Once you get the hang of it or if you're up for a challenge, I suggest moving up to wax paper or trays. Note the middle section, there's quite an opportunity to catch some air. ;)

Best time to go: After a workout with your friends. :)
author: Toni A.

description: Wow. These slides are so awesome! My boyfriend and I went here after seeing these reviews and it was great! The funny thing was it was mostly adults there, and not that many children. The witch was nowhere it sight, and everyone had a blast. I highly recommend coming here. If you're an adult make sure you lay down on the slide instead of sitting up, you'll almost get booted off the slide on that bump!
author: Molly H.

description:
OMG OMG OMG!!!

If you like slides at all, this is definitely one to try.....at night might i add.  Even though there's a sprayed on warning that says: Park slide opens from sunrise to sunset.  Try to contain your excitment, keep quiet and you'll be just fine, but you didnt hear that from me. har har har.  

Thanks to my girlfriend for discovering this slide, i tried it for my first time last night.  I still can't believe it's in such a cutty little neighborhood.  So i grab a couple friends and we went sliding at around 11PM and boy was it GREAT!  Here were a list of things we brought:
-  nice thick jacket (but not too thick because you'll get stuck in the slide, it's kinda narrow)
-  crappy jeans and shoes
-  flash light (for a night time high speed touge =D)
-  and last but not least... some McDonald trays...they work so much better than cardboard (CAUTION: HIGH SPEED

If you decide to go for the first time...YOU WILL ENJOY IT!  (NOT SAFE FOR SMALL CHILDREN!!!)

WORD OF ADVICE: take the right hand lane ;D
author: Mike D.

description: Eh, underwhelming.  Definitely had this on my 'must-dos' for a while now but was sad to find it quite unimpressive.  Granted, maybe I'm not much of a slide person, but it got old fast.  Neat concept but wouldn't recommend it for more than a side stop drop by on the way to some other destination.  Grab cardboard at the bottom of the slide, take the stairs up, give it a whirl, and call it a day.
author: Alice Y.

description:
"Wheeeeeeeeeee!!!!!!!!! Ha ha ha ha ha ha haaaaaa!!! Oh my god, that was hilarious! That was so much fun! Ow, I scraped my arm. Ha ha ha ha ha!!! Let's go up again! Whooo-peeeee! Ha ha ha HA HA HAHHHAAAA!!!"

This is, in a nutshell, my experience with the Seward Street Slides. I went with a friend the other day and we laughed hysterically, giggled uncontrollably, and basically had smiles plastered to our faces the entire time we were there. If you want to have fun in the city, forget about high rent prices, politics, gas guzzling SUV's, and feel as joyous and carefree as you did when you were eight years old, go to the Slides. They're da bomb, Yo.
author: Nuvia C.

description: Can only give it 4 stars now, as they've started locking it up at 5pm.  I sympathize with the neighbors' need for relief from drunken bone-breaking revelry, but 5 is a little too soon for me.  And for that matter, whose job is it to come every day and lock the slides?
author: gar l.

description:
My parents first apartment in the city was right around these slides, and even though they had moved out of the hood and into my childhood house when I was born, they still took me back here many a time.

I haven't been back in a year or so, but you are really never EVER too old for these slides. They're even more fun after brown bagging it for a night.
author: Allyson S.

description:
Thank you San Francisco for keeping one remnant of my childhood alive. While lawsuits have ruined every other playground and piece of playground equipment, it's good to know at least there is one place where a kid and an adult (sometimes the same person) can still have fun. 

Have you been to a playground lately - everything is wrapped in bubble-wrap and soft foam. Monkey bars - gone. Tornado slide - gone. Swings - gone. I remember as kid doing cherry drops off the monkey bars onto a pit of gravel. They have even taken dodgeball away from kids because it may be unfair and feels like bullying. One time in the 3rd grade a kid hit me with a dodgeball so hard it left a bruise for two weeks. It's ok because the next week I nailed him in the head and he had to repeat the 3rd grade - TWICE. No wonder kids today play video games all day - there is nothing good to be outside for. Thank you overzealous parents and lawyers for f*cking up America even more. All we need is more cuddled and overprotected kids turning into whining adults. Rant over.

Bring back my playground equipment with lead and sharp edges. Until you do, the Seward Street Slides will have to do.

The right side IS faster. And Crisco, a cafeteria tray, and tandem slide down is not a good idea - trust me.
author: Arin N.

description:
Whenever the grandson and I finally reach a targeted distination. . We punch our fist in the air and go "woo hoo"  . . . . good trick to teach a kid.
What is totally cute is watching a 2 1/2 year old holding a cardboard trying to climb the stairs to reach the slides . . again and again. . totally funny. . . then with the little tyke on my lap - arms in . . .we go wizzzzzing down. . . then up again, down again . .you get the drift. . . 
Where have I been. . . to have missed out on a public concrete slide waaay out in no man's land. . .you have to. . have to try it. . . it is sooooooooo much fun. . .
author: Kea C.

description:
Hell Yeah!!!! More fun than a barrel of monkeys! 
I'm still a bit of a scaredy-cat, so I only did the slide on "sliders" left, but I aspire to one day slide down the right side with my bum planted on a peice of tupperware like one very brave soul I saw there! 

Shhhhhhh, don't tell my b/f!
author: Michelle D.

description:
The boyfriend and I went here today. It was super fun, not to mention surrounded by beautiful houses and gardens.

If you have no fear of broken toes remove your shoes to shimmy up the side. 

We raced. I won. :)
author: Penelope C.

description:
5 star hands down :)

To me, the fact that the two old witches in the house next door are always watching you with evil eyes and will come out and scream every 5th time someone shoots down the slide makes it even more thrilling!!! 

My advice to you is to either 1) go down quietly, 2) bring the neighbor's kid with you - since you won't be allowed on the slide without one or 3) scream at the top of your lung as you come down and take off as soon as you hit the ground.... Otherwise, the witches will come out and eat you... serious! 

Oh and bring the cardboard box or sleeping bag like everyone here seems to say unless you want to get stuck midway. The view of the city from up top(if you walk further up the hill) is amazing too. Bring a date :) Totally romantic.
author: Kwan H.

description:
these slides warm your heart- unless you're a chicken. 
Only reason ever to go to McDonald's? To steal a tray for slide-time. Trust me, you'll fly. Also- work hard at trying to stand up as you finish, if not you'll be kinda screwed. Hands in the car at all times, and watch elbows. If you're there at night it really is a good idea to be shhhh...
author: Rhubarb M.

description:
C to me: Where is Douglass? I have never heard of that street.

Me: It's here..It's here..oh nope it's Collingwood..Oh it has to be the next one..Oh oops..

Finally we hit Douglass and then Seward.  I heard all the wheeeees and got excited. C got nervous as he had no idea where I was taking him! He actually stopped me and did not want to go further until I told him.  So, I had to tell him.

The yays and wheeeeeees could not be escaped as much as I tried to keep my mouth shut.  Wheeeeeees had a great time!!!
author: Shilpa K.

description:
WEE! WEEEEE!!!! It awesome! It's fast!

I haven't slid like that since... I've never slid like that!

...might take 1/2 star off for the dog poop that my friend stepped on! =0(
author: Chon Q.

description: I flew off the end of the slide into a tuck and roll.  8)  The left side is ketchup, the right, mustard.  The red and yellow paint is quite faded now though.
author: andrew l.

description: This is a great mini-park but too much attention is spent on the slides.  The top half of the park is a neighborhood garden that is awesome to walk and sit in.  Also great, but overlooked is that you can see one of the very best views in San Francisco by walking to the top of the park and maybe 100 yards to your right to the open hilltop known as Kite Hill.  Its a panoramic view from past downtown to past the ballpark, the bay and the Berkely Hills.  On a clear day, you can see Mt. Diablo. If you see Bill, he created the garden.  Please thank him.
author: Steve D.

description: Slides are tons of fun, but try not to make too much noise as the neighbors are easily agitated
author: Andrew M.

description: Hiked up here from Castro Metro station a strenuous task.  When I arrived there were padlocked gates across the slides preventing use.  There is a  paved path next to the slide at the same angle but there was no cardboard present to try this option
author: Paula S.

description:
Oh man, is this a city gem. At first sight, I thought they were going to be bigger after the reviews I had read. Let me tell you, they don't need anymore height. We went down several times each and made friends wit the other fun loving people doing the same. It's great fun. Next time, we're going to bring a picnic and stay a while.

Some advice: wear covering, it is easy to get concrete burn on your arms or scraped knees when your skin is exposed.
author: Cat S.

description:
If you see a thicker piece of cardboard with holes in it, that's the one to use! I go on the left slide (faster, but less steep of a dip)...my booty gets stuck going down the right. 

Great place to take kids of all ages. Everyone has a blast. :)
author: Giselle U.

description:
Completely, unexpected fun! For the first time in a long time, I'd found my inner child coming out to play. 

Tip for first timers - Use the left slide, you can definitely catch a few more feet of air time. Use caution!!
author: Casie C.

description:
Thank You Yelp
This place is awesome. It totally made my trip. I had to go to SF for a business trip - not enough time to do much else --- but there was enough time to go here. Even just a little while on these slides is sooo fun.
author: Sharon M.

description:
mercy. it is a serious bitch to find this place. my map implied that douglass connected to seward st from the north, that 24th hits eden, and that you can turn off market to get here. all of those ideas are lies. 

this is sposed to be kids only, and closes at sunset. our group of adults still showed up on a wed at 9 pm, and had no problems, except the house next door slammed their window shut. several dog walkers went past and nodded hi. one even told us we REALLY need to steal some plastic trays from mcdonalds if we want to go fast. but we are too much of pussies to do that. 

of the two slides, the one on the right (outside) is better, cause if you are wearing short sleeves and aren't careful, you can scratch your arm up on the inner one.
