the key to going fast is to get the largest piece/box of cardboard you can find, so your feet are up too, nothing is providing any drag. otherwise it's easy to slide off your cardboard.
author: Anna S.

description:
This was soooo fun! I felt like a kid again...the "playground" which consists of 2 concrete slides nuzzled in between two homes was empty except for us.

I took the day off work that day and it made me feel like a kid ditching algebra class...it was great!
author: Suzy Q.

description:
WOW - - - looking at these from straight on - they don't look so steep, looking down, they're kinda steep. Talk about exhilarating! Weeeeeeeeeeeeee is right! I would have given 5 but my friend flew off and hurt her tail bone. Make sure you have someone 1) sober enough 2) strong enough, to stand at the base to keep you from flying off.
Oh you catch a little air too.
author: melissa h.

description:
After having livid in and around the Castro for four years I finally found myself with a group of friends at the Seward Street Slides.  The adventure brought back the joys of my childhood of sliding down slides with a new twist. The dirty and worn cardboard and the cement slides made for an unforgettable experience. 

The best part was when my friends and I all of whom were there for the first time and all over the age of 25 were told by a 7 year old that were were going down the wrong way. "To go super fast you need to give yourself a hug when you slide down" he told us. After taking is directions we did in fact achieve a higher speed. So to where ever that little blond haired blue eyed boy is I'd like to say thanks and perhaps I will see you next time I stop by the slides
author: Jeffrey F.

description: The slides are a blast. Probably the best fun for free that you'll get in the city, besides watching bum fights. The second best part is the crazy lady! Oh man if you like watching people lose it for no apparent reason go to the slides and provoke troll lady. It won't take much. Just laugh and have a good time with somekids on a sunny afternoon and out she'll come. Snarling and hurling insults. Don't be intimidated...just laugh and point and she will really get worked up. Oh man bring a video camera because someone needs to YouTube this!!!
author: Sonja D.

description:
Crazy Fun!!!!   

Make sure to bring some cardboard so you don't wreck your pants. 
A plastic tray from McDonalds would also work. 

So far this is the best place I've ever been in San Fran. 

P.S. Bring some booze!!!!
author: Johny D.

description: Hands down one of the better things to do in San Fran. A few minutes from the main part of the city, the small street Seward holds fun that is unforgettable. I recommend going down face first on the slide with a little cardboard as your vehicle of choice. The best part is the little air you getting going down the big drop!
author: Vin P.

description: Yes I am an adult and No I do not have children... so I brought my mom.  I will always be her baby so that counts.  So maybe I shouldn't have come wearing a tubtop sundress.  I left half of my elbow and my right buttcheek on the second bump right before catching air and flashing my panties to the other non kids below.   Good times.
author: Cotille D.

description: As trite as it sounds, these slides make you feel like a kid again!
author: Rose K.

description: After hiking a mazillion hills in search of the impossible-to-find Seward Street Slides rendering my calves so sore I could barely walk for two days afterwards, imagine my disappointment upon hearing children's laughter and feeling that it would be too creepy/inappropriate for me to even try the slides. Kind of like being the fat kid in a dodge ball game. The pimpled braceface at the school dance. Waa. Maybe when I have children I will come back here -I hope to live right next door- and actually be able to try the slides.
author: Rachael S.

description: This definitely goes on my list of "poo that makes SF freakin awesome". Stop torturing your out of towners with Union Square and cable cars. THIS is what makes SF special.
author: Rennie L.

description: From the reviews, I expected 10-story slides that went through tunnels and rushing water and hoops of fire and upside down loops and orgasms. This wasn't quite what the slides ended up being, but I'm sure I would've been a lot more impressed had I been drunk...still fun and a great find nonetheless.
author: Mimi L.

description: Went there today at about 2pm and the slides have steel gates with locks at bottom and top and in the middle built into the slide totally preventing sliding.  They were draining water from the rains and there was mud puddle at the bottom of the slide.
author: William G.

description:
Well, the slides are fun, but I have never been cursed at so much or yelled at so loudly than I was by the people who live to the right if you are on top of the slide. It was 9 pm on a Thursday. There were two of us. We had been there for a total of five minutes when she first came out. We were not drunk. 

She said her children were trying to sleep, but I'd be surprised if anyone within a mile could sleep at the volumes theses psychos were yelling. After using every curse word imaginably, I asked if she kissed her children goodnight with that mouth. She then told me to go back to San Mateo. Not sure what that meant, but if you are from San Mateo, I'd take it as an insult.
author: Kaveh A.

description:
oooh ... i'm not the only one who's enjoyed the seward street slides both as a kid and as a big kid!

if you've stumbled across these reviews, bookmark this place now!  or click on the "View Larger Map/Directions" link so you can check it out in person right now!!

the tiny little slides-only park is located on a really cute single-lane street.  and i'd say don't worry about bringing cardboard because there was plenty sitting around when we last went, but maybe that's because a huge asian tour group had just left.

if you're a rookie, i'd suggest going down the slide on the left (if you're standing at the top, looking down) first, because this one is less scary.  the one on the right is for those a little more adventurous, as you do catch some air in the middle and you pretty much get shot out at the end.

pure enjoyment.  but there's no point in racing because the slides are pretty much synced.  and even though it sounds like it'd make the slides10 times more awesome, don't go down headfirst.  i would imagine a lot of blood and/or chipped teeth resulting.
author: spiff e.

description: The Seward Street Slides: the REAL San Francisco treat.  Bring cardboard!
author: Sid D.

description: Had an interesting experience at the slides. Walked through Castro and felt like I was on an easter egg hunt to find this place. Approached the park and immediately saw that the slides had the yellow barricades blocking a full slide experience. I did not know that the slides are closed Mondays. I'll fully admit that I am a rule breaker. I still sneak into movies and whatnot. I went up to the halfway point and slid down twice. Didn't scream hoot or holler but I could hear someone rustling in the bushes at the top of the park acting as if he wanted to be noticed. As we were leaving this middle aged gentleman who obviously lives in one of the adjacent houses starts on this very strange passive aggressive forced tangent towards my Mom and I. Talking about how Yelp ruined this park, that German people are coming at 2:00 am drunk and stomping all over his garden and how the slides are going to be ripped out and relocated in another park. He never full came out and said he was mad at us but it was obvious that the sight of the slides themselves raises this guys' blood pressure. I had a chuckle to myself and said good day.
author: Aaron L.

description: I've been to the Seward slides twice and it is an absolute blast.  Today, we invited some family from out of town to come by.  Unfortunately, the slides were closed, with steel barriers placed at the top, middle and bottom of the slides.  Not sure why, but I assume it is because of the vile lady who lives nearby.  At my last visit, she came out and berated a group of young people for their noise level.  They were being very reasonable.  She is foul and profane.  Still, if the slides ever open up, it is a great place to bring kids and friends.
author: Nathan T.

description:
If it weren't for Yelp, I would never have discovered the awesome Seward Street Slides. Though I understand the concern about them becoming too popular, hordes of shorts-wearing tourists, their spouses and children descending (or ascending, depending on your point of view) on this sleepy residential street and wreaking havoc on the neighborhood and themselves. So I will not divulge the exact location of the slides here. Those that know, know; those that don't - keep lookin'.

So for several weeks after reading all the glowing Yelp reviews about the slides my inner kid has been poking me in the ribs to find them. And, there being only so many inner rib pokings a person can stand without going totally and irreversibly cuckoo, I finally set out on my quest last night. It was foggy and drizzly out, and I still had not recovered from bronchitis I caught last week, and there I was traipsing on darkened streets of upper Noe Valley. At first I walked right by the slides without realizing they were there; only after turning back on the tiny street did I finally notice the entrance to the tiny park - and it is small, a narrow sliver of steep hillside with a cute little mini-park (more like a botanical garden) on top and the infamous twin slides at the bottom. I'd say that half of the fun of the slides is in finding them in the first place - it's a real treasure hunt.

At the bottom of the slides there was a pile of cardboard sheets in various states of disintegration. I picked a likely contender and walked  the steep incline to the top. Mmm... I remember reading on Yelp that the left slide (as viewed from the top) is the steeper one, so I picked the other one for a first attempt and braked with my hands and feet as I slid down. Hmmm, not bad. Let's try again, this time a bit faster. Whooooop-OOPSIES -oosh! Cool! How  about the more dangerous left slide? Whoooaaaa-OOPS-howthehelldoyoustopthisthing-oh. That's it? Then I tried walking up the rims of the slides while pulling myself up by holding on to chains strung between metal poles. A big tree (eucalyptus I think) growing near the right slide (as you look up) has grown right into one of the chains; this can't be good, it's hurting the tree and besides, the chain can literally saw through the trunk as the tree grows. Something needs to be done. Well, I've gone down both slides about a dozen times that night, gone up the steep rims on both sides, and here's what I think: the slides are lots of fun at first, but the fun has a tendency to wear out quickly. I mean, there's only so much you can do with a slide - you go up. You go down. That's pretty much it. I thought they could have been built longer and maybe curvier to make them more fun. A big part of the fun, like I said earlier, is going there for the first time and not knowing exactly where they are. Now that I know, they will be a good occasional stopping-off point on one of my nocturnal walks. After that - there are other hills to climb and destinations to explore. So - Froggy gives the slides four hops. And don't worry - the secret is safe with me :)
author: Froggy V.

description: This place is so fun, I'm not even upset that I tore a hole in my $70 jeans when my cardboard sled lost its structural integrity on the way down.  Hell, I think it's made them more stylish.  Great fun!
author: Eugene F.

description:
hands down one of san francisco's best kept local flavor secrets... and thank you yelp for bringing it to light!

this is just good clean FUN. you go incredibly fast and absolutely catch air in the middle. i'm surprised i didn't fall after landing because you hit the ground with a lot of impact!

we did not come with a child, breaking the "no adults unless accompanied by a child" rule, but there wasn't anyone else around so no one could bust us.

also- if you put a piece of wax paper underneath your cardboard it increases your speed substantially

my only regret is not bringing my camera!

can't wait to race again
author: Brianna H.

description:
Hello, I have read over 15 reviews of this slide and want to correct inaccuracies and add crucial must have info about the slides. This article is only a compliment to a full description, but as it is, it is the best you'll find.  I am, I believe the official Seward street slides master. I have been here a total of 6 times in the past 3 months.  That is august 2007 through the end of September of this year. I can give you incite into this playground as the city deems it, that no one else has, with the most crucial and up to date information available to ensure your enjoyment of this exceptional location.  

First- There is a city sign that says, "No adults allowed without children."
2nd- People have broken glass on the bottom of the slide in the past and it poses a threat.
3rd- Small flecks of glass in the sand underneath the slides exist.
4th- There is "very" terrible parking late at night.
5th- There is a lot of very well worn, dirty cardboard there for your use.
6th- At night precipitation causes a lot of dampness on the bottom portion of the slide and 3/4 of the time the slide is too wet to go on at night.  This because you get soaked and it prevents you from gaining any sort of speed
7th- Sand is essential to a quick ride down, so is a proper newish cardboard for you to enjoy your ride properly. 
8th- Keep your elbows at your side at all times or they will get very hurt.
9th- Once your committed to the slide do not bail out because you will get more hurt that way.
10th- I have seen a naked man walk past me at this slide
As a note to those who are willing to go out of their way (p.s it's not near Castro its a five minute drive from Castro) and as a total secret which I don't want to get out since it will ruin things for me, I will tell you a that which you are not ordained to know about this place.  Please at least, please, keep this to your self.   It's a great place to drink... outdoors... at night- that's all I'll elaborate to.
NOW please be thankful to all the yelpers out there who came before me with their huge contributions to this community, it truly is a community; IN homage to them I write this review. Thank you for helping yourself *arrogant

Please fix not so much grammatical and punctuation errors but focus on content elaboration and errors of this kind any more attention grabbing that I can include or silliness I need to remove or incomprehensible sentences or style remarks would be much appreciated.
author: david t.

description:
a trip to seward street wasn't plan at all last night!

so after a good, light sushi dinner, it just came to mind about the slides that the yelpers were reviewing/talking about and i suggested to the beau to check it out...and off we hit 18th, made a left on douglass and right on seward.

when we got there it was already 8:35p and there were only 3 teenagers sliding on the "now popular" concrete narrow slope!!!

the area was littered with cardboards and we helped ourselves and picked the appropriate size that will fit our arses!

going down on that slide was awesome! the beau and i were back in our kindergarten year! i was screaming on top of my lungs and i think i waken up the neighborhood, as well as a dog who started barking!!!

we had a good 15mins of enjoyable, silly,  fun on this slide!

i suggest that you wear appropriate clothing: pants and a long sleeve t-shirt..something to cover your legs and arms, for you can get an abrasion easily, because the beau did!

THRILLING!!!
author: Nelle A.

description: I found this through SF Weekly. That issue ran an article on best places to do, eat, etc and  mentioned Seward Street Slides. I have been living in SF for a long time and have never heard of it until I read SF weekly. I took my kids to the Seward slides. We really had a blast sliding down with these discarded/re-used cardboards. My kids asked me to bring them again and I did...this time I brought my husband along. He also had a blast!
author: Melody S.

description: One can of Pam, One Fed Ex box, One broken finger. One Awesome night.
author: F B.

description: This place kicks ass. They never build dangerous playgrounds anymore, so anything that harkens back to the splinter-causing, metal-skin-burning, cement-scraping of our youth is excellent. This is an excellent place to go 1. late at night 2. dressed in drag 3. drunk and 4. with cardboard in tow.
author: Esther H.

description: I took a few out of town friends here and we had a blast. I left the park with scratches on my knuckles and elbows, and plan on going back sometime to bomb one head first. Easiest, cheapest way to feel like you're 6 years old again.
author: Devon S.

description: Recapture a moment of your youth! Great for all ages and fun for the whole family. Sliding down on a plastic lunch tray might take you out, BUT! It would be the most spectacular way to go.
author: Kim L.

description:
one of the best natural fun day i've had in a long time!
seward slides are definitely worth taking a day off and dragging your friends and family of all ages to (make sure they're physically able and adventurous people because you have to walk up a hill over and over AND you'll probably end up with a few bumps and bruises by the end of the day.)

here's a few tips:
1] bring some large pieces of cardboard. there's probably a few lying around at seward, but they've been used AND may be moist!

2] wear sturdy, old, comfortable pants! half the time you end up sliding on your ass.

4]pour sand on the slide... it makes you go faster! but BECAREFUL! if you're little you might catch air and fly up and hurt your bum!

3] if you cant take pain... stay off the slide!
author: Lynn T.

description: Fuck yes!  I love these slides!  I could hangout here for an entire day.  I was pretty nervous the first time after seeing how fast the kids were going, but after the initial run I was good to go for many more.  My friends and I took videos as we were sliding down and they are really funny to watch.  Bring your camera!
author: Jenna M.

description: I took my camp group to the slides and we had an amazing time...we got some great pictures and video of us on the slide...watch the one on the right and keep your arms in! My kids got banged up, my arms were raw and the landing with wax paper on the bottom was killer! I taught my kids how to have fun with pain...they loved it!
author: Erin L.

description: The slide is great fun, but please be polite and don't come late at night.  It is torture on the neighbors, who hear folks screaming down the slide several times a night, night after night.  That's really not cool.  If folks can't control themselves, the City may one day close the slide and then the fun is over for everyone.
author: Victor O.

description: How the neighbors don't sit out their windows with pellet guns is beyond me. That being said, this park rocks. No cardboard necessary!
author: Justin H.

description: Next time I am bringing a sheet or two of wax paper! Wheeeeee!!!
author: Charise B.

description:
so much fun but make sure you check the slides first for dogshit. i have heard that the neighbors get upset about people screaming and being loud so what they do is throw dogshit along the slide to prevent people from using the slide. just a warning. oh and you get a bit more air on the right side slide.. enjoy! 

p.s - i heard that there is another one in the east bay that is even better... gotta find it!
author: Calama T.

description: This place is amazingly fun...from what i've been reading, bring some wax paper and you'll fly down the slides. if you're a lil scared of flying, cardboard will do just fine. the fun factor is definitely worth all five stars...my scratched up arms for being too wide for these childrens slides makes it worth four. good times overall
author: Nate F.

description:
i should have known to bring my own cardboard, but there was some lying around for us anyway. who cares where it's been? best part about this place: the sign that states, "no adults allowed unless accompanied by a child." it seems the tables have turned. oh, how they have.

we had no children in tow, so we were breaking the law - which i like to do anyway. we grabbed cardboard and headed up top. i made my brother go first to test the contraption because, well, i'm the frikken oldest. i say what goes! he makes it down without incident, so i decide to take a run. once you're over the initial fear of that vertical drop, you try to figure out how to go faster. you start racing, "ok, this time i'm on the left side! and quit cheating!" i quickly changed from a 29 year old professional (haha) into a six year old, albeit at 190 pounds and covered in tattoos.

these things are fun, once you find out where they're hidden. it's definitely recommended to not have a hangover when sliding. jostling around the brain housing group and climbing the steep incline to get to the top does not do a headache justice. outside of that, this place is a blast.
author: Jeremiah W.

description: My cousin read about this place on yelp and we finally went.  After initially being a bit skeptical, the Seward Street Slides rocked!  It wasn't so impressive at first glance... I mean, it's gray concrete, lots of cardboard boxes laying about, and some scraps of wax paper.  But, then you slide and it's like you're 5 years old all over again.  You get a lot of speed and air going down those slides.  We started racing (the west slide, I believe is faster and gives you bigger air) and landing perfect 10's at the end.  Some of the kids at the park started egging us on and getting us to place wax paper under that cardboard boxes for more speed..whoa.  That was a bit intense.  I felt flat on my butt in the tiny sandbox and definitely bruised it.  Three days later, I'm still sitting funny but it's all good.
author: Aileen L.

description: After our initial thrilling trip down the slide, a crazy woman came out and yelled at some people down near the bottom who weren't even sliding.  My friend and I looked at each other and simultaneously said, "oh shiiiiiit!".  We devised a plan to slide down one more time and run like hell before the devil woman could find us.  And call the cops on our asses.  Turns out the park closes at sundown.  I feel for her though, that would suck to live there.  Guess it's time to move...
author: Rosie F.

description: After eating mexican food and getting boxes from the place, we go on an adventure to the street slides.  I had heard of these and was interested.  It wasn't what I expected.  These slides are for little kids?  Really?  We went late at night.  Sometime after 10pm.  And while no crazy people were running after us calling the cops it was enjoyable.  You can slide down on your back or even your stomach while hearing the cardboard boxes grinding away.  The right side as you face down is the faster steeper one and the left is more of a bunny slope.  Watch out and be safe!
author: Jerry V.

description: WEEEEEEE!  Free slide-y cardboard fun.  Though, it's pretty tough to get to if you don't have a car.  Get a car and go!
author: Andy H.

description: Next time I'm bringing wax paper. These slides are not scary people. Not scary.
author: Kelly S.

description: It was a perfect end to a fun filled evening.  After bar hopping in the Castro my BBF (bussom buddy forever) said we had to go here.  After getting lost looking for this hidden jem we even refered to the map on yelp! (4 stars to yelp and iPhone). I used some discarded cardboard for my ride down because it is a bit steep.  it was fun! Howling with glee as we slide down! At 2am! (my apologies to the neighborhood!)
author: iced capp. y.

description:
inner -child? hell its fun no matter what!
fun yet kinda scary, if you have a good piece of cardboard you'll get some air and then that not so inner child comes out and you'll think 
"damn i can really bust my teeth on this thing!"

does anyone know if the golden gate slides are open or not?
author: Nate C.

description: I was turned on to these by TODO magazine, you know like the dog, and have been infatuated ever since. They are one of my favorite places to go after a night of heavy drinking in the Stro or the Mission and an extremely good way to sober since you have to hike up that god forsaken hill to get to them. Also a good place for a date. I don't know how many first kisses I have had up there.
author: Ryan O.

description:
i made the mistake of going down the slide on the right.. while sitting on a home-depot-medium-sized-movers-box.. while holding onto my camera so i can record my first trip down.

who knew that 5 seconds can go by in a blink of an eye? and that i would be launched that far out of the slide? sooo not prepared for that. 24hrs later and my entire backside still hates me.

that was painful. and i had to call it a day after one more trip down. 

but it was well worth it.

oh yeah and we got yelled at too. and it was 3pm!
author: Erik S.

description: I'm writing this review whilst tears stream down my cheeks.  These are the slides of my childhood, the slides that I've spoke of and searched endlessly for as an adult.  I came to believe that they must've just been a dream, a fast fun dream.  But they do exist, I've been driving up and down countless streets and I've performed endless internet searches to no avail, then tonight while casually browsing Yelp, bam, there they were.  I'm so happy, I'll be there tomorrow to bring back all of those happy, happy childhood memories of sliding down then hiking up the hill endlessly till the sun went down.  It'll also be a relief to all my friends whom I've gushed about these slides to, I'm sure they were beginning to believe it was all in my head.
author: Frigga G.

description: I smashed a fingernail. Kyle put a couple weeks of scrapes on his hands. I took a spill and met some dirt. Before going down the slides you pick up a fast-looking piece of cardboard from the ground, or, if you're an expert or stupid, bring your own and cover it in wax paper. Someone had brought a lamp to the park and just left it. These are reasons why these slides are awesome.
author: Brian S.

description: These slides were sooo much fun! We decided to try some local flavor on Yelp to see what to do on our week long trip to SF and this popped up. We  did have to hike up a humongoid hill to get to it, since we had no car, but aside from that it's a short walk from the Castro Muni stop. Also if you're up for it Kite Hill is nearby and offers an amazing view of the city with a romantic bench all by itself.
author: Rassamee H.

description: Shhh... my inner child and I are having a moment. Wheeee....!
author: Aaron L.

description: There's nothing like sliding down a big concrete slide on a piece of cardboard to incite the inner child in you to come out and play.
author: April B.

description: Now replete with the elements of everything destructive and wacky and fun.
author: Today Y.

description:
so much fun! 

bring wax paper because you go way faster than on regular cardboard!

i thought the signs that said "no adults unless accompanied by children" was a cute joke until a bitchy neighbor got upset at people laughing and having fun and threatened to call the cops. lame.

honestly, some of the most fun i've had in a long time! GOGOGO!
author: Jaei P.

description: One of my favorite "gems" in the city with which to surprise my friends.  Bring wax paper.  And afterwards you can walk up to kite hill and find the swing attached to a tree and look out over the city - also thrilling as you feel you may fall down a big hill.   I know lots of kids go down these slides, and I feel like the smaller they are the faster they go, so I would recommend they slide with an adult if they are less than 5.  I saw one kid ka-kunk her head big time on a dip on the way down, and they are concrete.
author: Sonia V.

description:
It was 7pm just after sunset on a Sunday when we headed out to surprise our local friends with some slide fun. Boy, were we all in for a surprise when we arrived. As soon as we walked over, a middle aged lady raced towards us on a rampage and began yelling and screaming at us about how the slides were closed after sunset. She was so angry with rage her voice and body were shaking. We all stood there in shock, not able to get a word in edgewise. We had to laugh after a certain point at this lady's completely out of control ravings about how all the people who come to enjoy the slides had ruined her life. 

The lady stormed off into her house as we stood there in shock commenting to each other how inappropriate the encounter was. A couple minutes later, as we stood there (dead sober, not sliding), the lady returned and began yelling at us again. A kid in the house popped his head out of a window and shouted "GET OUT, GO HOME!" - it was a completely crazy scene and we simply marched out of there as quickly as we could. 

....Calling all therapists- check this lady's head. She is more dangerous than the slides will ever be. Calling all cops, this lady is disturbing the neighborhood with her loud rantings. Calling the paramedics- check this lady's blood pressure- she needs some heavy medication.

Morale of the story: 
Do not go to the slides after sunset. 
Don't take anyone who is prone to violence or easily aggitated to the slides or expect a fight with crazy neighborhood people.
Try to keep the slides a secret, it is unfortunate that a few disrepectful people have driven these neighborhood folks totally insane.
author: Brooke S.

description: after a day of drinking and smoking in the sun @ Delores Park, the last thing you want is a super steep and fast concrete slide to finish up your day :) i can't believe they made this thing for kids.
author: Ethan B.

description: My grandfather used to take my sister and I here when we were children! Thanks yelp! I can't wait to go back with a strip of cardboard and slide til my hearts content!
author: Maryanne R.

description: The Guardian's Best of the Bay let this bad boy out of the bag a couple years back and I have been meaning to thank them ever since.  BoB is hit and miss but this one is out of the park, no pun intended.  In a crap mood, head to the slide.  Feeling great, head to the slide.  It just makes everything better.  This place was designed by a kid back in the day when a planning commission issued an open design invitiation, so the speed, design, space and over all experience just makes more and more sense as you start at the top and make your way down.  Bring a handful of sand with you to the top to kick it into 6th gear.  Just be prepared to literally launch off at the bottom (tuck and roll).
author: Porfirio R.

description: Yay! These slides give you major air when you fly down them!
author: Full T.

description: I'm giving Seward slides 5 stars, even though my partner Donna A broke her back on her very first run. Seriously. 5th vertebrae...compression fracture. So be careful on your first run until you ready for the speed...and the dismount.
author: Chris R.

description: I'm sure my rating's affected somewhat by nostalgic childhood experiences here, but who cares. Getting injured is definitely in the realm of possibility so take precautions against it. The best time to go is on weekend afternoons when all the kids are around. They're smaller than you, so be sure to knock them out of the way and get to the front of the line. Don't forget to run away from the disgruntled/angry parents waiting for you at the bottom of the slide (OR you could fight them. I mean if their kids were pushovers, you should have no problem with their parents).
author: Martin S.

description:
over-hyped on yelp. don't get me wrong, it was fun and happy time. but because of all the yelp anger by the residents that live around the slides, i was scared to scream with joy after that crazy second hump. i thought that any second an angry neighbor was going to come out and throw eggs at me. even if it was a wednesday at around 7pm. 

but thank you yelpers for bringing my awareness to these hidden castro secret slides.
author: Renae C.

description: Went here with my girlfriend and her mom after hearing about it on Yelp... Very fun and completely out of the blue in this charming little neighborhood. One note to sliders... if the Taco Bell plastic trays are still there when you go - be careful. I've got a bruise on my back after flying down the slide and catching some serious (at least in my memory) air with a hard landing... but totally worth it.
author: Mark J.

description: When you slide down, you are overcome with feelings of anxiety, nostalgia, and euphoria.  But just like heroin, it's never the same (like the first time)...
author: Ezduzit S.

description: Good times. For the first time in the two years I've been with my fiancee, who was born and raised in SF,I found a hidden gem in SF that she actually didn't know about. And we thoroughly enjoyed the slide.
author: Robert L.

description: Caught some air on the slide this weekend.  Why aren't there more adult slides in the city?
author: Amar P.

description: Sigh.  The slides made me feel old.  And lame!  Let me preface by saying that we were out walking around but I wasn't really dressed to go zooming down some concrete slides.  And it was one of those so-foggy-it-was-pretty-much-raining days.  Anyway, we got some good cardio in walking up the hill, and there was a cute family riding the slides with their kids.  This is when I felt old: because the kids were showing me how to ride the slides.  The first time I went down I somehow slid off the cardboard (another tip: bring your own cardboard, or you'll be stuck with whatever yucky soggy stuff is lying around) and just got stuck sitting on the concrete.  I'm pretty sure i was laughed at.  Anyway I managed to make it down once without making a complete ass of myself (maybe too late) and gave up.  I think I need to go back for another try :)
author: Leslie R.

description: SOOO much fun.. I felt like a kid. Make sure you don't have too much to drink beforehand or the results could be ugly.. as my friend discovered. (I apologize to anyone who witnessed that)
author: Sarah W.

description: The highlight of an otherwise less than mediocre date where I never called the guy back and now every time I see him he makes a mean face at me and averts his eyes.
author: Marcus C.

description: Uh, to the person who said "no cabbie in SF has heard of the slides" WRONG!  I'm a cabbie and I know all about em.  I just wasn't planning on sharing this little local fun spot with those not deserving!  Kinda like the fact that I do not take those who are not cool to underground clubs.  The very few local gems that we have need to be kept somewhat to ourselves.  Which is why I was disapointed to see this being posted..  I won't mention where you can  find more slides similar to these :)  This cabbie knows about those others also!!
author: Carol O.

description: aww...i always thought this was a secret place for adults to be kids again, but oh well, the yelpers found it. Memories of the night before my 25th birthday...or was it the morning of? who knows. good times though, good times. yeah, you should bring your own cardboard just in case, sometimes there isn't any left there to use. Check it out.
author: Mama Jaz C.

description: Pretty fun little place to check out.  Doesn't really provide hours of entertainment but it's a nice day activity to kill some time.  Good for all ages.  We found cardboard pieces around the slide, but after reading some of the other reviews it might be worth bringing some wax paper.
author: Michael N.

description:
Hey out there,

      I've been going to these slides since the opening day; June 14th 1971. Although I wish people (in general) wouldn't trash the sand pit, I can understand the need to have some killer nighttime fun. 
Now, for the real sliding facts:
1. The use of cardboard is wonderful on a dry day.
2. Polar Fleece anything, and gunny sacks work on foggy days, but not at night.
3. A plastic food tray from Mickey D's or Burger King's, really is the best for at night, but you have to be careful, because it (the plastic tray) makes you go really fast. So fast, in fact that you can catch some serious air on the hump above the dip, and even clear the sand pit at the bottom, altogether.
4. Stop complaining about getting hurt. You're sliding down a concrete slide for christ sakes.
5. If you're interested about the history of the slides, hike to the top of the hill, and go visit the Corwin St. Community Garden Message Board.
6. Did you know that the slides in Golden Gate Park were designed by the same architect, but the city made him dumb 'em down, for safety issues.
author: Dashiell M.

description: I never thought a slide could kill me until I took a trip down the Seward Street Slides. Dangerously fast. Surprisingly fun. Awesomely free.
author: Fabian G.

description: Awesome. I've been here with a 33 year old woman and an 8 year old boy and had a blast both times. An awesome place for a date. Ignore the skid marks on the side that smell like poo. Somebody tried to do some poo art but aside from that, the slides rock.
author: Mario T.

description: I used to live at 15 Seward ... The big house 2 houses down from the slides. Definitely a great late night diversion and hidden SF treat. It is one of those fun dangerous things that I'm surprised the city has not been sued over. The park behind the slides is also beautiful.
author: Jon S.

description: Wow.  Definitely the best stone slide ever!!!  Definitely bring  your own cardboard (or plastic trash can lid, or whatever  you might think will make you go faster...).  There's usually a lot of cardboard scraps there, but often times run down or caked with dog feces.  If you've got nothing better to do, definitely a must.  It's pretty much a novelty.  You can only ride the slide so much before you think to yourself... "what now?"
author: Darkie L.

description: I forgot all about the Seward Street Slides until seeing it here on Yelp.  I use to live around the corner on Eureka @ 21st .    I would take my dog for a walk to Kite Hill and we would always swing down to to this little park for a slide.  I don't think my dog cared for it that much, but my friend's five year old loved it.
author: Kurt K.

description:
sliding is awesome - even better after a round of sake at some castro sushi joint.

be sure to: wear long pants. bring cardboard or wax paper. be considerate of those who live nearby. keep your hands and arms inside the vehicle until it has come to a complete stop.

even my uptight gay boyfriend had to admit this was fun. (i let him beat me in a race.)

there may be better, faster, taller concrete slides in the city, but the seward street slides are still damn fun.
author: Sarah B.

description: Super fun! at 2 in the morning! except i still have a scar from it.. scraped my elbow and caught some air. Remember to tuck in the arms! I think the right one is faster!
author: Mina T.

description: Steal some McDonald's trays and race any kid under 12 you can find. Good times. Also, you have to try going head first--atleast once.
author: Anjel V.

description:
for a good 10-15 minutes of fun (probably more for kids)
super fun and fast cement slides - i've gone twice and there has been 
more than enough cardboard there. and last time, there was a mcdonald's 
plastic tray, which i highly recommend if you can get your hands on one. 
riding down on the tray was way faster than dry cardboard. 

if you're planning to go, plan to get a little dirty cus HELLO it's playground. both times i've gone it has pretty quiet (never more than 1 or 2 other people there tops) AND if you venture to slide when it is wet or raining, definitely try going down on wet cardboard. your bum will get wet but it is FAST.  you fly off the end of the slide by a couple of feet.
author: Deena M.

description: I thought I was going to die the first time I went down the slides. Then I tried it again and again and again!! Crazy super fun slides in the middle of a random neighborhood! My suggestions: wear jeans (or long pants), bring a camera, and have a cardboard box with you just in case (there are usually flattened boxes lying around, but you just never know...).
author: Pauline A.

description: While these slides might look like they are "for kids", it is important to take caution - one careless move and they can turn around and bite you in the rear.  But just as all things in life, if you're careful, and take care to respect these dangerous slides' natural limits, you will find a truly rewarding experience. See how high you can jump on the right-hand slide's twist/bump; find out which types of cardboard work best for speed, which work best for handling, and which work best for stamina. Instead of top speed challenges, why not try distance?  With a little care and patience, you too can extract hours of enjoyment from these deceptively simple slides.
author: Geronimo G.

description: Free fun. Don't forget cardboard to slide sown on!
author: Katy D.

description: We came here for my 20th birthday and it made me feel 7 again.  Mostly because there were a bunch of kids running around and smacking eachother with cardboard.  Just goes to show these slides are great at any age!
author: Jenn F.

description: Nearly 2 stories tall. Bring cardboard - longer thin pieces around 14" x 30" should suffice. After the third try, flew in the air for .01 seconds.  Well worth it. Next time I may bring a broom to sweep up the extra gravel around, it causes way too much friction on those slides.
author: Judy L.

description: this has got to be one of the funnest things I've done that did not require any money. We tried it without the card bpard but our jeans got dirty and it was pretty slow. Next time we used the card board and I nearly ate sand when I got to the bottom. Watch out for the dip. Great time with friends and especially with that someone special. Not reccomended for small children.
author: Justin G.

description:
these things have to be some of the most random human creations I've ever seen in my life. 

i don't think you need a piece of cardboard since they are super smooth, but if the thought of touching the concrete makes you uneasy (Pansie)  then you can go for it. 

but these slides are damn fun - i like the fact they are super tucked away and somewhat of a "secret" (although if it's on yelp it's not that much of a secret). but it is a great place to have a little adventure into SF.
author: David D.

description: Free fun.  Polyester pants recommended.
author: Tony Q.

description: TIP: Put some sand down the slide and sand under your cardboard. Whoa that's fast. I'm wearing a helmet next time.
author: Jennifer G.

description: Memories....! Ah the old concrete slides of my youth, I had almost forgotten you. As a little girl I had some great times on these and as an adult, well some things never change.  Can't wait till my next visit.
author: Jasmin L.

description: How could I have forgotten about this place. It must be almost 30 years since I've gone down your sleek cement on a piece of cardboard. I'm in. Saturday. Are you?
author: Valerie V.

description:
awesome
after a party in noe valley, we walked home at 4 in the morning, just so we could take a detour and hit the slides. we went down twice, and hit the road, but not without our burns from the concrete on our elbows to show for it.
author: Markell M.

description:
we went during the afternoon on a thursday. Honestly, it was sooo much fun! I get scared easily so I was really nervous. After i went down the first time I was shaking and I could barely stand from the rush. I went down so fast that if i wasn't wearing my sunglasses i would have hit my head against the side. My sunglasses got chipped and scratched!

We got in trouble though from the lady that lives nearby. (the one everyone mentioned) Whoops I guess we were screaming too loud. she was really mean...so we decided to ride down the slides one more time and leave. it was so hard to not scream on the 2nd time down. But definitely worth going out! Whenever friends come visit I'll definitely be bringing them to the seward slides!
author: Jess O.

description: If you have a free afternoon with nothing else to do, the Seward Street slides are it.  It's a teeny park and little hard to find..you feel like you're going through someone's backyard.  But once you get there you'll be entertained for at least half an hour.  Be sure to bring a piece of cardboard to ride down on.  If you're extra adventurous try waxing the cardboard-it gives you extra speed and you will go airborne.  Warning: not the best idea for small children. I saw one particular child bang his head on the cement slide, catch air and then face plant into the sand below.  But for adults...hold on tight and have some fun! You'll definitely catch some air.  Also fun done in pairs!
author: Danielle W.

description: What a great place for a birthday party.  It makes  you feel like a kid again and if  you are a kid it is just straight fun.
author: Phil M.

description: If you haven't done this, then you gotta! It's super hard to get to (like a mile or two up the hill from Castro) but it's worth every last breath! Make sure to take a cardboard box with you or you'll be up a creek. And take a video camera with you. You won't want to miss the look on your face the first time you go down. It's a thrill!
author: Rebecca J.

description: The adventure of finding this was a lot more fun than the actual slides.
author: Eric L.

description:
On 3.  1, 2, 3 go!  Steph brought me to this jewel of a park today.  It's been a while since I've had this much fun in a park.  We must've ridden the slide at least 7 times.  You can catch air midway.  On one run, we slid so fast that we both landed on our butts at the end of the slide.

Great fun and a nice work out if you run to the top.  Best of all, no lines!
author: William L.

description: I'm surprised some bureaucrat hasn't found a reason to shut these down.  They are fun and free - it ought to be illegal!
author: Dean F.

description: Salt and cardboard are helpful for gaining speed.
author: Kelley B.

description:
These slides do indeed rock.  I've been taking my son here for a couple of years now - he's 6 yrs. old and a total daredevil and these slides are the perfect "fix" when he has the need for speed.  

Sometimes I worry that someone is going to call child protective services on me for taking him there.  It is a bit of a "child endangerment" situation.  But WTF, what's a childhood without a few scrapes and bruises?!?!  

And if you think that you catch decent air when going down as a semi-adult type of person . . . just imagine if you only weighed 60 pounds!
author: amy b.

description: Whoever said it was cool to pounds shots and race each other down the slides...burn in HELL!!! I am sooo beat up and bruised but it was a hell of a time. Definitely going back again...and again... Besides, chicks dig scars, right?
author: Minh D.

description: I can't believe this is on here! I thought this was a hidden gem where I could go to unleash my inner child! But also, my boyfriend has an amazing skate trick on here! Check it out on youtube.com. Just type in Jeremy Reeves, Crime in the City (City skateboards rock!) and when the window pops up, you will recognize the spot immediately!
author: Marie S.

description:
My 3 year old son loves these "secret slides". He has a blast. 

But watch out he really got air last time and I thought he was going to fly out on one of the turns.
author: Michael M.

description: What a SCREAM of a great time!  This is one of SF's best kept secrets, 300 reviews notwithstanding.  Just a few steps up the hill is one of the prettiest views of the city.  There's a pretty garden just above the sildes where you can sit and enjoy the plants and a picnic.  And the slides are incredibly fast and fun.  It is true, as the other reviewers note, that there's a woman who lives next to the park, who seems to relish in repeatedly opening her  window to tell people off.  But even her appearances cannot diminish the fun (can you say "AHHHHHHHHHH!") of the slides!
author: Sue S.

description: the FUNNEST THING EVER!!!!!! don't worry about bringing your own cardboard because there are plenty already there!!!! Maybe a little busy with some kids and families but we went on a weekday around 6pm and it was perfect....no one around!!!! be careful though they go fast!!!!
author: Christina A.

description:
This crazy little "park" gets four stars for its uniqueness as much as for its fun. I can't imagine who had the crazy idea to take what must have been a useless hillside site and turn it into a "park" that has nothing but slides. So very San Francisco. A little dirty and rough around the edges, but great fun nonetheless. My wife and I took our two year old daughter to the slides after hearing about them from a random person on the street. It was a blast, and it took us into a neighborhood we had never been in (we don't live in San Francisco) Using cardboard, we were able to slide a lot faster. You won't slide a whole lot without cardboard, but there were plenty pieces around when we got there. Without cardboard, our two year old slid on her own and had a blast. Great for kids, great for adults. We also used Yelp to find a coffee shop and a great place for lunch nearby (Chan Chan cuban cafe - awesome)
I only gave three stars because it is a bit dirty there and the other reviews had my expectations high of huge death defying slides. They are fun, but not the giant things I expected.
author: Charlie T.

description: Next time bring some waxed paper.  You'll fly!
author: Amy P.

description: Can't believe I had never been here before. Loved it except for the smeared excrement on the walls, but we are hardcore sliders and did it anyway.  Will be back with plastic gloves next time.
author: Sweetwatermelonsugar H.

description: OMG! This is still around! I've been looking for this for a long time now! I remember when I was a kid, our YMCA counselor/guide brought us there for a mini-field trip. We'd grab a bunch of sand, throw it down the slide, steal some kids abandoned cardboard-board and use it to slideeee down that thing. Yippie! I also remember my YMCA counselor was chased by a goose all the way from the park to the car, to the park, then back to the car, and etc. until our teacher transported us all safely back to the van two at a time. Too bad for his red shirt, and for the many pecks he gotten. But then again, too bad for me and my wedgie too...Thanks Mr. YMCA counselor for saving me from that crazy goose!
author: May S.

description: going drunk and getting yelled at by the neighbors is AT LEAST half the experience.
author: Kimberly N.

description: I used to come here a lot as a kid... but now that I'm grown up I don't seem to go as fast as I used to. But still a fun hidden treasure.
author: Laura B.

description: alas, this makes me sad!  all these people knowing about these secret slides.  i lived in this hood when i moved to the city 12 years ago.  these were where we took our special visitors to show them a good time.  there was never ANYONE here.  they were great fun.  and about a block away, there is a sweet view of the city (well, mostly the castro) from kite hill (which is where we lived).  so, 3 stars for the secret being out.  thanks a lot, yelpers!
author: Cami B.

description:
this rocks!  young and old can enjoy hanging out and finding new creative and dangerous ways to descend. @#$%& 
note:  do not use sand to to faster - this wrecks the slide.
use wax paper, waxed cartons etc.  thanx!
author: eric d.

description: no cardboard? no worries. we brought a pizza box with us but we didn't even use it. jeans and your arse are all you need! i was glad i was convinced to come here ... despite my friends being pretty tanked from doing shots of tequila all day long at a bbq - whereas, i was completely sober. these slides are badass. watch out for your elbows though ... as a couple of my friends got nasty slide burns.
author: James J.

description: had total fun!  make sure to use cardboard!  the less friction the better chance to get slightly airborne / lift!!! ;)
author: Sebastian K.

description:
the only reason i have to deduct a star is because of the savage landing.  now let me preface this by saying i really dont do anything half way.  im a balls to the wall kind of guy.  i grabbed a brand new piece of cardboard made sure i was on the right hand side made sure there was no other part of my body that could drag me down and went.  the result was painful.
at the drop i was going to fast got mad air and came down with a hard thump mad raspberry rash on the inside of my arm created by the wall not only that but also with so much speed and the drop i could not lean forward and ended up flat on my ass.  a lot of times.  i have to figure out how to master this thing.  the goal?  go down on a skateboard deck without wheels that will be bad-ass.
author: Anthony Y.

description: to die for.  as in, you could/might die on the slide (not really.)  this is a local treat... and a true locals-only test.
author: Geoffrey W.

description: Went with some friends after reading rave reviews. After climbing two very large hills, we reached our destination. It was, to say the least, disappointing. Our jaws dropped as we watched small children enjoy the slides. They're small and not nearly as exciting as advertised.
author: andrea a.

description: super fun! although, you shouldn't wear your best clothes here. they'll get dirty and maybe ripped. the one on the left when you're standing on the top is definitely more thrilling. i was airborne for about a sec in the middle on the ride down. kinda out of no where tho. look for red bars and listen for people sliding.
author: Rhonda H.

description: thank you for offering a few moments of childhood joy after a long day of taking the LSAT. all future clientele will be referred here.
author: Sari W.

description: yay! what makes san francisco so silly and fun. just use the cardboard so you don't burn your bootie.
author: elsa m.

description: I lived in the Mission for many years and usually hiked these hills for some exercise daily.  I have never been here before up until last Wednesday.  This has got to be one of SF's best kept secrets.  These slides are located in a residential district in the cuts of the Mission/Castro hills.  We were lucky to find parking right in front of the mini park (if you could really even call this place a park).  I could see how parking could be difficult there though but you could probably say that about any place in Frisco.  Anyhow, I chickened out and didn't try the slide but my husband did several times and so did my four year old son.  They said it was super fast and fun.  I didn't see any other kids there besides mines but then again, it was getting late outside.
author: Maryanne D.

description: An amazing and fun experience, until the woman next door decided to give us a lengthy and condescending speech about "being aware of our surroundings" (it was 5 in the afternoon, btw, not the middle of the night) and said that my friend's sincere apology was "not the appropriate response to the situation" while she mocked my boyfriend because I guess he was standing in a threatening or rude position.  I understand that the neighbors are trying to maintain a nice, peaceful, EXCLUSIVE neighborhood, and I'm sure they have to deal with rowdy kids and shenanigans all the time, but there are more polite and, frankly, San Franciscan ways to deal with a situation aside from yelling out your window and talking down to three people you don't even know.  They completely sucked the whimsy out of our experience, which was, up until that point, delightful.  My advice is to squeal like a little kid and don't get disheartened when this happens to you, because it probably will.
author: bronwen g.
